review_title: Chief Engineer, Program Engineer, System Engineer Positions
pros: Lockheed Martin is a highly successful company focused on DoD and Energy markets. It has opportunities in many career fields, worldwide. The organization is large enough to afford personnel a chance to work in areas they can excel. Employee ratings are conducted via a managed performance system with an equal opportunity to be recognized.
cons: The size of the company and length of major contracts does make new initiatives major undertakings and product delivery contracts, lengthy.

review_title: Good pay but very frustrating company
pros: Flexible schedule, good pay, decent benefits
cons: Project management has very limited power but we take full responsibility in the government's eyes when another department drops the ball.  Most departments and even managers on your team will do their best to push their work on you.  Negotiate a good salary when you are initially hired because HR does not care if you have been with the company for years and are still at the low end of the pay spectrum.  HR is no value added and most overhead departments are also no value added.

review_title: The current leadership recognize hard workers that make significant contributions, and promote accordingly.
pros: Flexible hours, and the 9x80 schedule is great. Starting pay is competitive. Just over one year of being employed, and a $10,000 raise was offered. Benefits are standard for the industry. This is a great place to work, especially if you are motivated to contribute. Depending on the project, supporting soldiers in the field is often an added sense of fulfillment.
cons: Managers can be stuck in a mentality of doing things the same way as they have always been done. This limits progression for new ideas, and potentially, a higher efficiency of performance. That being said, mangers seemingly are always willing to listen. Overall not many cons.

review_title: Good if you are not looking for much excitement at work
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Washington, DC
pros: Good salary and good people. World reputation is strong. Multiple jobs in the company if you wish to move. Training is adequate.  A lot of my comments might be biased because I worked on-site at a client. Good salary and good people. World reputation is strong. Multiple jobs in the company if you wish to move. Training is adequate.  A lot of my comments might be biased because I worked on-site at a client.
cons: Politics are quite high when you move up. A lot of pleasant speak to your face, then different actions later on. Politics are quite high when you move up. A lot of pleasant speak to your face, then different actions later on.

job_title: Configuration Analyst, Senior in Palm Beach, FL
pros: Diverse enviornment.  Lots of opportunites for work in different business units.  Extremely ethical and will not tolerate harassment or violence.
cons: It appears that LM is top heavy with Baby Boomers getting ready for retirement and therefore there are no advancement opportunites.  Most, if not all, career opportunities are for the younger 20 -30 year old folks.  If you don't have a college degree, don't bother to apply.  HR is a tool of managment and will protect the company at all costs.

pros:
- Top notch ethics
- Always focused on customer and tax payers best interests - great solutions
- Will stick with a program and a customer's mission through success
- Large reach across the technical space means there is room for every kind of skill
- Treating people well is starting to return as focus
cons:
- Starting to lose focus on top end technical problems and solutions, growth is diluting our strengths
- Assumption that median-level salaries is good enough is causing our best to leave
- Increased size and approach is starting to foster arrogance towards our customers
- Employees are increasingly having to fend for themselves

review_title: Great Place to Start a Career
pros: As a young professional, Lockheed Martin is a great place to work if you are passionate about manufacturing and engineering. Their leadership development programs offer employees the opportunity to have their graduate degree paid for and allows employees the opportunity to relocate on the company's dime.
cons: On average, responsibility and salary increases tend to be on the slower side. Promotions are based on tenure rather than ability. With many layers in management and supporting roles, career advancement comes slowly. Switching companies often appears to be the best way to progress at this firm.

job_title: Program Planner in Fort Worth, TX
pros: There is an onsite Gym.
cons:
Management is ok with you moving…as long as it is within their department.  It looks really bad if that manager allows too many people leave the scheduling department. I have had 3 jobs canceled on me because my Sr. manager made it extremely difficult for to leave.
Also, the atmosphere is really bad.  It is still old style management in 4 person cubes and no windows.  It is a 5 minute walk to see the outdoors.  
You are expected to be at work for at least 40hrs, anything above that you can telecommute without a mother may I.  However, come performance appraisal time you will be penalized for not averaging 43hrs a week.

pros: You will get the opportunity to learn a broad spectrum of disciplines, if you choose...or be very specialized, if you choose.  Opportunities to move between several similar programs.  If you are a VP or Director, it is virtually impossible to lose your job.
cons: The primary customer is the US DoD, so availability of new, interesting work is at the whim Congress.  Which means a lot of starts and stops, uncertainty with each budget cycle, and unnecessary oversight.  In recent years, the company has stopped promoting even the highest performing people.

pros: Raises are ok. When you are direct billable there is no extra corporate work on the side. You do your job and go home.
cons: Their pay and leave is terrible. 3 weeks sick and vacation which is the worst in the industry for such a large government contractor. You can't negotiate that unless you are a V.P. or higher status. Management only cares about the client and there is no support for the staff, and that includes HR. I even complained to the Ethics Department due to a way that a situation was handled unethically and they never called me back to close the case. The company is a joke!

pros: If selected, you get to work on cool projects or programs like the Phoenix Mars Lander; LM is also pretty good about paying for degrees (both, BS and MS) in engineering from an accredited, "official"  school (NOT University of Phoenix or LaVerne).
cons: Information hoarding, personal agendas among executives etc. trickle down to the engineering level and poison the work environment.  You may have to work on weapons projects to tide you over until you find a non-weapons program.  The company culture mirrors the military command-and-control culture, in which higher-ranking people are always right.

review_title: Not the worst place to be, but much room for improvement exists.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Large company tends to have larger fringe benefits.  Location is amazing (especially if you live relatively close).  Many varied opportunities are apparently available, but sometimes it's difficult to move to other jobs within the company depending on your current manager's need to keep you.
cons: Reviews seem canned and do not seem to affect your raises, despite what is told to you by management.  Benefits are on a major slide - even more so than similar companies.  Internal project leadership (from a technical standpoint) can be lacking, sometimes due to a "leader by default" mentality.

pros: From spending a summer there, I saw that Lockheed treated their employees very well. The salaries were fair and there are many other perks the company provides. Depending on where you work within the company you help out on some very interesting projects. The company follows a 9/80 work schedule so every other Friday we had off.
cons: Lockheed has its own way of doing business so the learning curve is steep when it comes to acclimating within the business. There are many different processes and acronyms that you have to learn and most of what I did there as an analyst was never taught in any college. The skills are not very transferable.

review_title: Overall a good place to work.
job_title: Software Engineer Senior in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
Competitive pay + benefits
9/80 Work schedule (9 hours a day, every other Friday off)
401K contribution matching 
Vacation time rolls over (but capped)
Tuition reimbursement, however I have issues (see cons below)
Job security (no outsourcing)
Great work/life balance.  Employees are encouraged to take their vacation time.
cons:
Promotion / Advancement heavily biased towards seniority vs merit-based.
Political infighting between groups. 
Company maintains dead weight employees and shuffles them around instead of laying them off.  
Bureaucracy and red tape create a slow-moving work environment. 
Tuition reimbursement only towards a degree program.   Why no option to take 1 or 2 classes for professional enrichment?

pros: The pay is unbeatable for interns, and I hear (across cubicles and from other interns) that most students are treated very well.
cons: In all companies, there are employees and supervisors who are lacking in communication skills, respect for others, and overall ability to do their jobs.  I happened to have gotten stuck with a supervisor that fits all these criteria.  To be fair, I know several other interns that have had wonderful experiences with their co-workers, and having all of these productive relationships present within earshot of my cubicle is quite torturous.

review_title: A good place to develop skills to take you elsewhere
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Manassas, VA
pros: great benefits, very easy to get a broad experience base and transfer throughout many different company locations, experience with many different systems, within one company very easy to experience many different procedures and ways of thinking, many employees have worked many different functions and have a lot of experience and are highly willing to share lessons learned
cons: low compensation compared to peers, high performance is not rewarded well beyond average performance, HR is glacially slow and unresponsive and often resists promoting high performers to keep costs down, managers are highly inconsistent in quality and have little ability to recognize high performers

pros:
* You get to work on really cool projects that make an impact to our nation's defense (i.e. military  systems and fighter jets), science (i.e. weather satellites), and consumers (i.e. GPS satellites).
* Lots of different opportunities to find your niche.
* Plenty of affinity groups that you can join and executive leadership are very active in them.
* They actively promote mentoring.
* They promote cultural diversity and ethics.
cons:
* Very conservative culture.  You won't find beer bashes or decorative office areas like at Google or Apple.
* The promotion process is not very good.

pros: Every other Friday's off, many different locations around the world to work, flex-schedules depending who you work for. The stock continues to climb and the company is secure.
cons: I will speak only for the Aeronautics company, Fort Worth specifically.  The culture is in need of some help.  The company lacks diversity (minorities and women) in leadership positions. Top down culture where only leaders are expected to make the decisions.  Employees are expected to do as they are told, instead of managing the work products they are responsible for. Many of the company perks are slowly being taken away (i.e. pension, education reimbursement). Not dealing well with a shift in their employee population.

review_title: Massive pressure, long hours blame culture. Lots of promises no delivery.
pros: There were lots of promises before I started. Great pay, flexibility and team works. Lots of training and good culture. - Boy did they fail.
cons: Systems do not work properly. The induction programme is never run properly and training for the role was never provided. I was in essence set up to fail and be blamed. They had signed a contract to claim a milestone and then threw it at the new guy with no support and wondered why it failed.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Insurance, Vacation, limited Flex Time (based on title), 401k match, on-site medical facilities, online PeopleSoft learning programs, limited tuition reimbursement, relocation, international satelite offices
cons: 20% performing actual job functions while 80% waiting to retire and collect their retirement which is not offered to new hires.   Depressing hearing old timers talk all day about their $$$$$ retirement with countdown clocks.  Discouraging environment with talk amongst selves, groups, departments complaining about how no one does their job or it's done incorrectly.  Seems everything is a corrective action.  View first hand how tax payers dollars are at waste.

pros: Has some good management, employees are nice if they are not over stressed, pay is a little better than most other places with the same type jobs.
cons: Allowing of bad managers to stay too long, very negative impact on employees, Benefits are getting worse over time and requiring more out-of-pocket, having a family is not the model that these benefits are for.  Single people will find Lockheed Martin the company of the future, married people, good luck.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Goodyear, AZ
pros: extremely flexible schedule, good work/life balance
cons: Lower pay, employees are lower skilled; this is not a place for IT professionals or new college hires; company does not provide technical training - " do it on your own time". Pension created a "golden handcuff" culture which results in A LOT of employees not actually wanting to be there and more interested in keeping things the same than delivering innovation and value to customers and taxpayers.  Security clearance jobs DO NOT pay more - at least in IT at Lockheed. IT careers will languish here technically and leadership wise. Many Work/office spaces have 30-40 year old Furniture and 10-20 yo carpet, etc that is dirty and worn. Work environment is less than average. Many Employees lack social and personable skills which effects culture.

review_title: It was exciting to be a part of a legacy, and contributing to a company that has such a great impact in the world.
job_title: Senior Structures Assembler in Denver, CO
pros: The best part of Lockheed Martin are the employees. Teamwork is welcomed and encouraged. Also, Lockheed Martin provides generous compensation and benefits, and encourages professional and personal growth.
cons: There aren't really any cons. As a Lockheed Martin employee, you only reap the rewards of what you put in. The only limit is what you set for yourself. Lockheed Martin is not a stepping stone, but rather a company you would want to stay with for the long haul.

pros: It's a job that provides a paycheck every week.
cons:
Just went to a High Deductible Healthcare Plan, minimum deductible is $6,850 to maximum of $13,500 depending on the plan you pick.
Yearly raises are minimal, 1.5% last raise.
When working overtime, salary employees have to work the first 5 hours uncompensated every week.

job_title: Senior Member Engineering Staff in Littleton, CO
pros: Large company with lots of work to do which helps with job security.  The benefits are good but could be better.  The atmosphere between co-workers is nice and makes it a nice place to spend a third or more of your day.  The flexible hours are nice but management takes advantage of it and "requires" employees to flex around appointments to save on personal and sick time.
cons: Large company where it seems there are the chosen few and the rest are just employees.  They cater to the new employees just out of college and seem to forget about the mid-career employees that are also looking for career advancement and professional development.

job_title: Software Engineer Associate in Moorestown, NJ
pros:
- 15k tuition assistance is hard to beat
- very smart people
cons:
- hardware can be outdated depending on your project.  some employees still have CRTs.
- I'm still early into my Lockheed career, but job growth is questionable and I'm not sure my salary will keep pace if I stay within the same company

review_title: Great Pay, Every Other Friday Off, But Lacks Diversity
job_title: Talent Acquisition Coordinator (HR) in Gaithersburg, MD
pros: Competitive pay, great benefits, travel reimbursements are all pros of Lockheed Martin. One of my favorite things about this job was the 9-80 schedule. (All employees get ever other Friday off.) This of course means longer work weeks, but the extra hours are worth the three-day weekends!
cons: The lack of diversity is a weak area for this company. It is highly dominated by Caucasian men. There are few minorities in leadership roles throughout the company. This limits growth in my opinion. *For the purpose of this post, "minorities" refers to ethnicity and gender.

review_title: You can get comfortable here, but if you are a dream chaser - Get in and Get out
job_title: Senior Human Resources Business Partner in Marietta, GA
pros:
Stable
Diverse Workforce
Smart co-workers
Benefits (401K, Salaried Savings, Medical Dental)
Early and Mid Career Development Programs (LDP)
cons:
Not the most inviting and enticing work facilities
Location of some plants are good while others are down right in-humane

In Transition to a more lean workforce / expect some layoffs in non-growth business areas
HR Management does not listen to its fellow HR employees who are entrenched in the business and know the employee population best.

This is a place where the stars are the engineers - the other functions just play a supporting role.

pros: If you have any background in Military Aviation then this company makes you feel right at home. Some policies change but overall amongst the ones that matter terminology and practices remain. The pay is good compared to other companies in the same market and the ability to work as much as you want is there.
cons: Sometimes you may feel as if your stuck in the advancement department waiting for higher positions to open up. The Union for the mechanics isn't flexible enough for all the locations of its members.

review_title: Great, Stable Company with tons of room for career development.
job_title: Multi Function Financial Analyst Asc in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Awesome competitive salary and great benefits. Focused on culture optimization in the workplace and a very positive environment overall. Engaging work and an excellent set of products,
cons: Fairly slow and archaic promotion strategy. Very rare to get early promotions prior to the HR parameters for time worked. Difficult to get performance based promotions without being in the right place at the right time. High intensity environment, probably not for everyone.

pros: Big company, so you can move to other spots if you don't like where you are. It's relatively predictable, since things move more slowly at a larger company - not like you need to worry about them closing their doors at a moment's notice. And the benefits are pretty good, considering the economy.
cons: All the issues of a corporate culture that has been around for a very long time - there may be some wisdom in the legacy, but with a changing economy, it's hard for them to stay competitive as an employer.

review_title: They are what the kids call "players"
pros: job security great, esp. if under 50
cons: toxic overly masculine, militaristic culture.  Year 1: we love you  Year 2: we love you but  Year 3: you are sucking, and btw no raise  Year 4: you do everything wrong, and btw no raise  Year 5: you better get obsessed with growth, or you just might be laid off someday

review_title: Work there for a few years to get some experience, then move on to greener pastures.
pros:
Lockheed has very mature Dev, Test, and Production operation processes, and well-enforced operation policies, which leads to a nice, stable environment.

Lockheed also supports and frequently wins new government and commercial contracts, so you'll get experience supporting a variety of different agencies & industries.

Technical leadership is strong - at least in terms of familiarity with existing contract support.
cons:
They're extremely cheap.  No bonuses, and the below-average raises often don't cover the annual cost-of-living increase OR the increased costs employees pay for their "benefits".  This is partially a result of being a government contractor, where income is somewhat fixed.

Uncertainty over contract renewals can also be stressful.

job_title: Systems Engineer Associate in King of Prussia, PA
pros: Lockheed Martin is a very competitive place to work, and the dynamics of the employee atmosphere is great. Many of the senior employees are always willing to go out of their way to bring the newer employees along, which makes for a very rewarding experience.
cons: Communication between the administration and the other employees lacks most of the time. Several employees along with management are spread to thin sometimes with their work loads. This leads to very few or short conversations about employee satisfaction and reviews on the quality of work.

review_title: Could be  good place to work, but defense budget cuts continue to loom.
job_title: Systems Engineer Principal in San Diego, CA
pros: Industry-leading benefits package, especially medical and dental.  Company is professional, and politics were there but not pervasive.  Company wants to do a good system integration job for the DoD, but budget uncertainty over the past few years in Congress makes high-level managerial decisions difficult.
cons: This is a system integrator, so if you are an engineer looking for interesting technical work look elsewhere.  Also, there is no grace here if there is a budget cut by the DoD.  You'll be given 2-4 weeks to find another position in Lockheed. If you can't (and 2 weeks is hardly enough time), then you are out the door--just like any place else these days.

review_title: Great Company with Good Values and Great People
job_title: Flight Test Engineer in Edwards AFB, CA
pros:
The people here make this company great. Very intelligent, friendly, and willing to help others succeed. You can learn a LOT from the people that work here.

As a young engineer, the corporation offers programs to allow you to explore the company and become a leader. Also, the job opportunities are very exciting and personally rewarding. 

The company offers a great benefit package, including a good amount of tuition reimbursement.
cons: Difficult to get promoted within the same job title. In order to get ahead in the company you have to switch positions, which means people who become experts in their field are not rewarded for their continued service.

review_title: Not Many Companies Can Beat Lockheed
job_title: Project Planner Associate in Grand Prairie, TX
pros: Great co-workers, fantastic managers, moral/ethical atmosphere, great opportunities to excel, flexible hours/work time, good benefits. This all creates the best work environment that I have ever experienced.
cons: Pay is not as high as I could make elsewhere. Many employees are older as well, so they are not very open to using technology to make processes easier and more efficient. There is also a disconnect between departments relating to project management (such as finance, technical operations, planners, etc) and this could be improved upon. Lastly, the work space (buildings) are not very pleasant, and should be improved.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Very flexible schedule if you are in the right group
cons:
Very few opportunities for promotion
Performance ratings are too formulaic and if your manager won't fight for you, you're screwed
Large corporation with their priorities in the wrong order

review_title: Great for college grads and retirees
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Manassas, VA
pros: Relatively lots of opportunities to learn for college grads. Very stable for people looking for places to retire at or just turn the crank for years.
cons: Stagnant technical opportunities for mid-levels: once you do something, you do it until you die, change jobs or retire. Despite of what management will tell you, there is NO way to change assignments once you get settled in. Also, salaries are super-stagnant: in 7 years of working I have never seen someone who is not straight out of college get hired. They simply can't afford professionals.

pros: Great company to work for with many exciting and cutting edge products. There are also many very bright and talented people who work there such as scientists, engineers, as well as non-technical business people. Very good benefits.
cons: Behind the times when it comes to providing a progressive work environment for its employees. Workplaces are out of date and could benefit with more modern environments to attract and retain employees. Too many people at the top have been there too long and have old school thinking. Limited opportunities if you are not a technical person. Company is only bottom line profit driven.

review_title: Full Time Systems Engineer (~1 year experience)
pros: Lockheed Martin is a very ethical company that cares about its employees. They lead the industry with many of their technologies and the workforce shows it. Working at Lockheed Martin, you have the opportunity to work side by side with some of the industry's experts, and they are almost always willing to help out in any way they can.
cons: Upward mobility within the same organization is hard to come by. The work is slow and there is a lot of red tape involved as expected when working with the government in the defense industry.

review_title: Loved working for Lockheed Martin!  My group was divested so I had to leave the company otherwise I would still be there
pros: I was fortunate enough to work for great managers who took care of their employees and recognized their hard work.  The programs I supported were challenging and exciting.
cons: Losing contracts but that's typical with all defense contractors.  LMC always made it a priority to find affected employees new assignments within the company.

review_title: Big salary doesn't always = happy employees
pros: Salary, Salary, Salary, Salary, PTO
cons: Company always trying to cut corners to save a $1.  If you work for Ft. Worth, you will get told NO when requesting materials and tooling to do your job. Safety is only considered when it benefits the company, not the employee.  Middle East contracts are run by people that have no idea the challenges and therefore make decisions based on bean counters and not actual necessity of employee. Safety and security of employee  are compromised to save $.

review_title: Bad pay for the work that you do
job_title: Material Handler in Hill AFB, UT
pros: Good breaks, sometimes around holidays they take us out to eat. Other people you work around are pretty cool in areas.
cons: A lot of walking, have to us your own car to get to certain areas, they pay isn't really worth all the work that you do. Most employees don't do their work and just come in and collect a pay check. No air conditioned buildings during the summer. Have to find a break room somewhere to eat your lunch. Not a loud to have a water bottle on you in a lot of areas even when its 90 degrees outside. Make you walk in horrible weather to the other buildings.

pros:
Smart people who are for the most part easy to work with
Stable
cons: Very siloed environments on the large programs, and very little interest in breaking down those walls. Middle of the road benefits, and general refusal to match salaries which is very ignorant and does not encourage those in the software industry to stick around

review_title: LM gets it right half the time
pros: Lockheed Martin has access to some of the most advanced technologies around. Its engineering staff are top notch. As a company, it treats its subcontractors and small business partners well (and better than peers do). And, LM adheres to its motto more often than not ("We never forget who work for").
cons: Lockheed Martin often finds a poor balance between its three stakeholder communities: employees, customers, and shareholders. Lowest on that totem pole are its employees. As a result, it suffers from high turnover.

review_title: A challenging but enjoyable place to work with good pay and benefits.
pros:
Excellent pay for good performance and many benefits including insurance, retirement savings matching, etc.
A challenging job environment and employee improvement structure designed to stretch your abilities.
cons: Very regimented way of writing code for defense customers who are very picky about minor things. There are many problems with having a cash-strapped single customer for a product. Not the most enjoyable workplace environment (just a cube farm) with laptops given only to management positions (so they can work from their near-constant meetings).

review_title: Overall good company but large turnover from younger generation
pros: Great technical (worked on extremely innovative products) and leadership experience if you were in specific programs that allowed growth.
cons: Pay for performance did not exist which meant very talented, young employees would leave to get paid higher by competitors. It is also extremely hard to move up the ladder if you don't know the "right" people or do not intend to stay for 20+ years.

review_title: Great place to start a career.
pros: Benefits are better than most companies but continuing to slide toward mediocrity. Golf isn't yet a requirement for upward mobility. Have worked with some very intelligent and brilliant people.
cons: Performance appraisal system uses forced ranking which destroys incentive for teamwork. Career advancement is nonexistent beyond the age of 40 for most people. Because the main customer is the government, there is unavoidable regimentation.

pros: Flex work week and that's about it
cons:
Low salaries, no relevant training, management is older and unqualified only in position due to years served, old boys club, conform or be isolated, no accountability, bully atmosphere, they say they have a mentor program but that's a joke, ethics, what ethics, HR is only there to protect the bad managers and image, claim they use best practices and leading edge which is the furthest from the truth.
mid year and end of year review is the worst I have seen and a waste of time, changes every year, lots of meetings and waste of time

job_title: Manufacturing Engineer Senior Staff in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Some of the best work experience you will ever receive, especially if your interested in working for a large company, if you get the right manager. It never hurts to learn a process put in place by a large internatiomally known company.
cons: Many times, because of the sheer size of the company, employees can get lost in the system and not receive the one on one attention a newer employee might need. A large portion of middle management is so worried about themselves, that they forget they are supposed to be leading a team not setting up their own next job.

pros: The company is filled with an amazing talent base of scientists and engineers and it is quite fulfilling collaborating with these great minds. Projects are almost always complex and interesting.
cons: The company's leadership is extremely shortsighted.  The innovation the company was built on is no longer as evident.  The performance objectives are based on how much revenue was brought in recently and the dollar amount of the projects you manage.  Contrary to what you would think--Innovation or out of the box thinking is NOT incentivized.

job_title: Financial Analyst II in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Good perks and work-life balance. Your peers and managers are general friendly and are willing to help out. Friends that you make there are great people as well. Stable company- this is where you go to if you want to work until you retire.
cons: Very structured and old school. Promotions take a very long time and is based on seniority. Depending on who your manager is, he or she can micro manage a lot which does not contribute to a nice working environment. Difficult to retain younger talents as the company is so structured it is not very conducive for millenials.

review_title: Cool projects, but outdated tools and processes...
job_title: Embedded Software Engineer in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Cool and interesting projects all over the board. Anything you want to do, Lockheed probably does it somewhere. There is a lot of opportunity as a new hire to try different jobs and move around.
cons: Very rigid military like culture. Processes are very outdated and there is a lot of resistance to any sort of change. This includes software tools and software development processes. Old cubes from the seventies and updates to work environment are very slow moving.

job_title: Configuration Analyst, Senior in Syracuse, NY
pros: I've been an employee for less than 6 months.  Here are a few things I like about the company: Competitive pay, flexible work schedule, job security, friendly and helpful coworkers, company values, and importance in both the local community, the US, and around the world.
cons: I've worked at many companies throughout my career; some large corporations and some smaller, more regional employers. Lockheed is obviously a large corporation, and it feels that way... very "corporate". It is missing the feel of a smaller company; the more personal connections between management and other employees the some other large companies have.

review_title: Once a family now a corporation
pros:
-flex time
-9/80 work schedule 
-401k benefits 
-dental 
-union (some states) 
-TONS of room for advancement 
-if you are willing to relocate your career is endless 
-Program management program is amazing (OLDP, ELDP..etc)
cons: As someone who's entire family has worked at LM for over 100+ years combined I can say it truly is a great place to work however, it has become less of a family business to just another corporation. I have moved to several states within the company and have yet to get awarded a relocation package, the benefits are changing substantially-to a high deductible plan, and not to mention no more pension.

review_title: Satisfying work, but lack of organization.
pros:
Challenging work. Good benefits package. Reasonable hours.
Projects can be leading edge and the employee community is strong and supportive. A good place to start a career, and very good leadership training programs if you can get in.
Above average pay and benefits. Good emphasis on work-life balance and flex time schedule.
Company encourages internal transfer to broaden skill base and experiences.
cons:
Lack of organization. Poor management.
Communication between management and employees is close to zero. Knowledge sharing and transfer can be difficult if originated from older generation of employees. First line managers are below average in terms of training and qualifications.

review_title: Lockheed Martin is a great company with many cultural and organizational challenges
job_title: Systems Engineer Staff in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Big Company with many opportunities with descent pay. The company has top notch technology and some great resources. Compensation in terms of pay and tuition reimbursment are good. The company has many positions and with some political savvy one can find a very rewarding position.
cons: Very bureaucratic and not very progressive in career growth. Hostile environment for minorities. The company has some organizational challenges. Many younger engineers leave due to the lack of advancement and perceived lack of concern for career growth and challenging opportunites. The company has some cultural issues it is seeking to address, but the leadership gets in the way of itself at times.

review_title: Great for the Younger crowd, but not so much for the seasoned professional.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Manassas, VA
pros: Pros -- Decent work/life balance (they don't work you to death).  Very good Benefits.   They are very flexible in terms of dress and schedule.
cons: Cons -- the pay seems to be on the low side of average.   Incremental/yearly raises are small.   They seem to favor the very young people for management positions.   If you have about 10-15 years of experience you BETTER be sure you hire in as a Level 4 (Staff), because if you don't you'll never advance.    I've been asking for a leadership role for over two years running, with no response from management.

pros:
Coworkers are friendly
Work-life balance is better than most places I've worked
If you get on an interesting project, you can learn a lot about military systems
Work is stable unless government decides to cancel your project, which happens
cons:
Lots of processes (which seems to be true for all defense companies, not just Lockheed) which can be extremely frustrating and time-consuming (and sometimes a waste of time)
Things can move very very slowly
Some people are not technically competent
Politics trump technical most of the time
Tech support is bad, and in general, there is a lack of good infrastructure, software, system for technical work to get down

job_title: Systems Engineer Staff in Owego, NY
pros: I have enjoyed working here and, although the economy tanked, there are still many interesting projects.  I find it personally rewarding to know I am working on something that may help my country someday.
cons: It is true that it's hard to get promoted when you get to mid-level unless you are part of the "in" crowd, but it's slowly getting better.  The new medical benefits are really horrible, especially if you have a family.  There is a definite reluctance to embrace change of any sort, especially if the change will increase productivity...

pros:
1. Depending on the program you're working on, there are some truly amazing things you'll be a part of developing.
2. Decent work/life balance.
3. Great people to work with.
cons:
1. Below average salary.
2. Promotions are almost non-existent. Without a dedicated manager pushing for your advancement, you will remain the same job level and pay grade for years.
3. Because of the tight security policies in place, expect to be working with very outdated software libraries, tools, etc.
4. Senior management clueless about the core technologies. 
5. Over promise (knowingly) - under deliver: very typical.

pros: schedule, benefits, location, job security, industry leader, some training available if you go after it, easy to move between departments
cons: You have to leave and come back to get a big bump in salary. You must go after positions yourself. There is no incentive for management to train or promote you. Many employees just riding a desk til retirement. Training is encouraged but most is difficult to get approved. Compensation is salary only - no bonuses for top performers. Archaic HR policies. Technology is the only thing "cutting edge." The rest of the company's systems, processes and policies are still in 1975.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros: Work/Life balance is great - I rarely need to work more the 40 - 45 hours per week.
cons:
Yearly reviews are directly related to how much money your project has brought in and will bring in. If you do an awesome job on a project that is cancelled due to no fault of your own you will only get a basic contributor rating, which can be kind of frustrating.
Also, your employment is directly tied to a customer contract. If there is no customer contract/project to pay for your continued employment then you will in a very short time find yourself unemployed.

pros:
The people were fun, the work was interesting, and I had the best manager to date there. Money was ok, benefits covered what I needed them to. 
3 weeks paid vacation and 12 days holiday yearly.
Good place to end a career at because of the slow implementation of newer tech.
cons:
Not working on newer technologies.  
When you find yourself in a defense budget cut (and you will) your skills aren't going to translate well to the work force outside the defense industry.  
The work wasn't technically challenging and my knowledge base suffered considerably because of that.

review_title: Ok place for entry level engineers
pros: Good pay depending on where you work, the benefits are good.  The company has a lot of projects to offer, and they make it fairly easy to transfer to a different facility if you choose to.  They give you plenty of options for career and academic  improvement.
cons: Lockheed Martin does not know how to keep their 0-5 year employees.  I was there for 3 years, and my managers were hanging a promotion over my head for the last 2 of them, but i never actually saw it happen before I left.  Management can be good in some cases, but horrible in other cases and don't always take the time to fully understand or appreciate certain situations.

job_title: Senior Staff Systems Analyst in Reston, VA
pros: Pension.... though I understand no longer for new hires.  Opportunity to work from home.  Supporting external customers can be more advantageous than supporting internal LM customers; LM employees could fair better operating under external customer processes.   Wide spectrum of products and services offers many opportunities.
cons: Limited/no support from managers.  Annual review process can have little value. Managers can discover no roadmap for success. To be fair,  LM is a huge company with many sites and cultures; pick wisely.

pros: 9/80 flex schedule, great place to learn from some very talented people, always something new to work on, good management flow-down
cons: Difficult to get needed training, even good loyal employees can get lost in the masses when it comes to job recognition, sometimes the bureaucracy gets in the way of progress

review_title: Fulfilling, stable work.  Can be overly bureaucratic at times.
job_title: Senior Mechanical Engineer in Littleton, CO
pros: We get to work on things that push boundaries.  Lots of job security.  Decent 401k. 9/80 schedule is nice.  Slowly adjusting to allow more remote work.
cons: Overall programmatic management and efficiency is poor, but that’s partly due to the customer (NASA).  Health care could be better. A little slow to adopt new technology and ways of doing things.

pros: Large company, always has employment opportunities.  They'll hire anybody with a pulse (not necessarily a pro). Initial salary  competitive with other  defense companies.
cons:
Poor work environment. Engineering merit structure promotes mediocrity. Young engineers show up with loads of enthusiasm and are beaten down into submission within a year or two. Not a place for the motivated, you'll be  frustrated  in no time at all. If your  a slug, then you'll be happy here banking of their DoD "welfare" system. The benefit package gets less and cost more every year.

The facility is outdated by today's standards, test equipment and tools  are not the most modern for a company that touts itself as being  a "center of excellence".

review_title: Lockheed Martin has a phenomenal resource in its people but they often ignored in order to comply with the Lockheed Way.
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Washington, DC
pros: Large company with numerous opportunities and a very good reputation in the government sector.  Education opportunities are plentiful
cons: Entirely too large to adequately take care of people and customers.  Positions are often left vacant due to an inability to communicate between divisions, and often managers are interviewing the same person for multiple positions which leads to an asinine form of competion amongst the same company with differing priorities

job_title: Systems Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: good pay, good stability, good balance of work and life, good benefits, the interview process was not bad, i just went in and answered some basic questions. for my position of systems engineer, it paid to be open to different kinds of things, and be a little broad, for example i had some interest in hardware and software, as well as business, which is good because lockheed gave me that opportunity to get a master's in engineering and an mba through the educational reimbursement program
cons: 9 hours a day, even though you get every other friday off.......have to go to work early, around 8 or 9 AM

review_title: Lockheed Martin needs a more youthful workforce and strategy
job_title: Electronics Engineer Senior in Denver, CO
pros: I work in space systems. The projects and technology are great, There are great opportunities to work in very interesting research. You will work with very skilled engineers and scientist.
cons: slow career development, slow salary growth = 3%. In addition it is very hard to try to work on different divisions. If you want a fast pace environment this is not the place for you. There is a ton of paper work and procedures that slows down you work. Some of it is unnecessary but you still have to do it. Doing business development is very slow and cumbersome with all the regulations.

review_title: Work-Life Balance, Steady Career Growth, Global Opportunities but YOU are part of that growth to make it happen.
pros: Flexible work hours, great health care package, challenging work, opportunities all over the world, something for everyone, and very ethical and diverse company make this company a great place to jump start your career.
cons: Although LM is global, it is hard to find opportunities you WANT in one location.  Salary is slightly below average and the bonus program is meager.  It is  easy to get stuck in one position and do the same things everyday.

pros: Company with a great reputation that is the producer and innovator of many defense products! Be proud of the work it does in for our armed service members and our nation.
cons: Alright now that I gave you the good stuff, think about this place.... most of the now middle management is the group of people that could not survive in the military in the 90's during the draw-down. So these people who work there are just there, they do not manage or think ahead, but add to this is that they are now 10 to 15 years of seniority And the frustrating part is they are now hard to remove to make the company perform better so they just exist in mid-level average.

pros: Relatively Good Benefits. Very flexible and accommodating.  They allow you a good work life balance and allow for flex time and are accommodating if you decide to pursue advanced degree well working.
cons: The performance review, ratings, and relative raises and promotions are really bad.  It is not indicative of the effort or work you put in at all.  Sometimes better managers will put in a good word for you and fight for your promotions.  But in general most won't bother.

pros: The salaries are good and, depending, what skill sets you have, there is room to grow and opportunities to move around locations.
cons:
A minimum work week is 45 hours (only paid up to 40) but you are generally expected to work closer to 50 or 60.  The politics are intense and career progression is largely dependent on making good connections up chain. 
As long as you are willing to make the company priority number 1 and can network successfully, I would recommend LM.

review_title: Finding out the company has no intention of following its own code of conduct, but uses policies as a weapon
job_title: Senior Staff, Engineering in Orlando, FL
pros: Interesting work, good compensation, career growth potential (provided you're willing to do what you management wants, regardless of ethics/integrity)
cons:
Dishonest management and HR (esp. to it's primary customer: the US government, management has no issue committing fraud, and demands employees follow suit or risk retaliation and potentially being fired for relatively minor policy violations while ignoring major infractions reported by employees)
Salary plan is not to reward for performance, yet to drive people to the "industry average"

job_title: Software Engineer Staff in Rockville, MD
pros: It's a large, stable company so if you perform then you can work here for decades.  There can be a lot of flexibility for working hours/schedule... but like many things at Lockheed, it really depends on your specific manager and project.
cons: This is not the place to be for Software Engineers.  Lockheed is a Systems Engineering organization with very little software engineering expertise.  Software is considered a tool like Matlab... so leadership has no appreciation for good design.  Most of the people writing software are educated in other disciplines (ex. Electrical, Mechanical, Aeronautical Engineering).  That would be fine except for the fact that 1000's of lines of unmaintainable code are written every year.

review_title: Mixed bag - Choose your program wisely
pros: Being a bigger company they have the financial resources to offer decent training. They have an exciting group of projects to work on and movement within the programs is possible for the right skill sets.
cons: There seems to be a lot of political games and management make decisions behind closed doors which doesn't instill confidence in teams. Team Leaders and Senior staff often don't have the support they need to manage both people and work. HR is based in US which means any negotiations take longer than they should.

pros: Good benefits. Reasonable pay scales at most levels.
cons: Very difficult to get promoted if you are not in specific sectors, or an obvious "ready for grooming" candidate.  Currently, the economic environment does not really allow one to pick and choose assignments.  The projects and come and go on a whim, without any guarantee of follow through by LM.  The number one complaint among my coworkers is the lack of opportunities that lead to roles the company consistently demands are necessary for proof of advancement.

pros: Lockheed Martin is a top rate corporation with a prestigious mission and name in the defense industry. I feel they offer excellent work life balance opportunity for growth and challenge and competitive compensation. I currently work for Lockheed Martin as a recruiter In the enterprise operations division and I love it! You will work hard but the work is rewarding and you will work around some of the brightest in the industry.
cons: None I can think of other then working for a large company you can be a bit In a silo but if you reach out to other divisions you can learn alot so this is not a major issue but more a typical norm in most any large corporation.

pros: Lockheed has a lot to offer to any employee if they are willing to put in the effort.  There is so much online training available if you want to spend the time to learn at your own pace.  One of the added benefits is the 9/80 schedule that has been implemented where you get every other Friday off.
cons: Lockheed is a very large company and like any other at this size there is some politics that go along with the territory but you just have to learn to move along with it.  Lockheed is constantly changing to stay ahead of the curve so if you not open to change then you will have a hard time achieving.

review_title: Good company but behind the curve
job_title: Software Developer Associate in Orlando, FL
pros:
Flexible work schedule. As long as you are at location between 9am and 4pm, you can adjust when you show up and leave around that. Also you get every other Friday off, but you work 44 hours the 1st week (9 9 9 9 8) and 36 hours the 2nd week (9 9 9 9).

Benefits are decent. Full health/dental/vision, 10 hours of vacation added per month. 50% matching for 401k up to 8%. Get plenty of company discounts in the area. They'll fully pay for your Masters as long as it's in a related field to what your position is, the program is accredited and you've been at the company for 1 year.

For at least the team I am on, plenty of work to do, good managers, plenty of people to learn from, encouraged to branch out to other projects, or teams for "stretch" assignments.

Relatively easy to move to different teams, departments and locations in the company. Just need to do a interview.

Formal mentor system and plenty of leadership programs and seminars to help you grow/learn.

Encouraged training hours and paid-for certifications.
cons:
Location security can both make you feel safer and paranoid. Cyber security policies as well.

Everyone takes their 'level' too seriously. Meaning, a new employee is shunned, ignored, given little thought to when talking to or debating a Senior developer/manager/etc. Little transparency with management to employees. 'special rights and privileges' given to higher up managers, etc.

They're behind the curve in both technology/skills used and workplace culture. They literally call their initiative to improve workplace culture: 'culture optimization'. Feels disingenuous, robotic and profit focused. Makes me think of when a company is trying to market to kids, you can tell they're trying hard to be 'youthful' when they're all too old. Same feeling with the manager is trying to figure out what their employees want.

Additionally, they use a lot of older technology. I can only speak on the ASP.NET web development side. No teams use MVC, only WebForms. With C# application development, only WinForms is used. But some teams are trying to get into WPF.

Confusing time-keeping system and budgeting between teams is a mess.

Lastly, all of the cubicles are solid blue and ugly. Doesn't help me feel motivated :/

review_title: Good Pay, Not the Greatest Job Security
pros:
The pay is good for the area
Housing in the area is cheap 
Decent Benefits (great on site medical)
Free to explore difderent programs for career development
Lots of tools and training for career development 
Great Relocation package
Company Contributes to 401k
cons:
The area is mostly rural
The raises are terrible
The annual review process is standard but terrible
Typical large corporation, treated as a resource and not a person
Job Security

pros: Good pay for the job. Excellent benefits.
cons: Poor supervisors, poor managers, poor adherence to standards, poor corporate structure (too siloed), poor to nonexistent mentorship, no compassion for work force as long as work gets done. No backbone from leadership to hold union accountable for their side of the collective bargaining agreement.

pros: Great missions, great people, flexible work schedule, 9/80 work week.
cons: Benefits have dramatically decreased in the 15+ years I've worked here.  Executive management and HR continually try to claim the opposite.  Also, talent is walking out the door every day, and I've seen nothing to reverse this trend.  The company is sitting on a ton of cash, and yet very little get distributed to common employees.  New bonus plan is an insult for mid career employees.

review_title: Lockheed Martin Transportation & Security was my worst professional decision.
job_title: Systems Engineer Associate in Rockville, MD
pros: Lockheed Martin Transportation & Security allowed me to take vacation as I saw fit.  There was never a time when I was asked not to take vacation.
cons: There is a lot of bureaucracy involved at Lockheed Martin Transportation & Security.  I was not given much work to do for the first six months of my employment and the work given was not indicative of my education or experience.  Management was not capable of alleviating my concerns and was content to bill me to the customer for work that I was not allowed to do and never actually did.

review_title: Work here only if you are desperate
pros: Lockheed Martin offers a very good benefits package, so for a new grad who is looking to pursue an advanced degree, it would be good. The workload is minimal, and the amount of vacation time you get per year is significant.
cons: There are severely incompetent people working there. Advances are based almost entirely on seniority, and not on productivity. The pay is significantly lower than everywhere else. Other companies look down on employees of Lockheed Martin, knowing that people who work there are generally lazier, so you get locked in as a Lockheed Martin employee for life after about 5 years.

job_title: Optical Staff Engineer in Orlando, FL
pros:
The money.  I negotiated a big boost in pay along with a nice signing bonus when I went BACK to the company.
Challenging work, which can make things interesting, frustrating, or both.
cons:
Cannot load software onto your own computer, plus you have to justify any software you want the company to buy.
Not quite sure whether or not your being watched . . . or when . . . 
Highly bureaucratic.
Regularly gives PAC money to politicians.

pros: Great career opportunities and great upper management.  Benefits package is better than most competitors.  The management is very hesitant to let anyone go.  Layoffs are extremely rare.  Even with the stock market crashing, Lockheed Martin stock is doing great and my 401k is still looking good.  The management here is worthy of trust and make every effort to be as fair as possible.  Company offers ability and flexiblity to work from home which helps a great deal in work/life balance situations.  Thanks.
cons: Cost of living in the Rockville, MD area is quite high.  Other than that the company and it's management are great.

review_title: Start your job here because of a great compensation package -- but don't stay too long.
pros: The salary and benefits packaged are great.  Business Week ranked Lockheed Martin the #8 best place to launch a career in 2009 and I'd agree.  Internships are pushed heavily as evidenced by the Business Week report: 65% of eligible 2007 interns received full-time job offers and 81% of interns with offers accepted.
cons: You may be in the same position for 10 years before being promoted.  If you don't plan on staying here for 30 years make sure you get out in your first five years.

pros: Flexible hours allow you to work as you please. You can come in and leave whenever you like as long as you stay within the guidelines. Another pro are the great benefits including insurance, vacations, and 401K
cons: Most of your business comes from government, so it relies on government spending. Another con is they offer certain benefits to entice you to join, such as Summer Flex (which allows you to take every other Friday off) but you are not encouraged to actually do so

job_title: Systems Engineer Staff in Marietta, GA
pros: Lockheed Martin is a very diverse company with excellent benefits. Of the places that I have worked, Lockheed is the only place that I have not complained about low salary or poor compensation.
cons: For advancement Lockheed places heavy emphasis on networking.  In theory, this may appear to be the proper approach, but in reality it is not. This concepts lends to favoritism versus technical knowledge. As it has been said on numerous occassions "it is not what you know, but who you know".

review_title: Engineering career advancement is a joke.
pros: Incredibly interesting work programs, such as aviation, planetary probes, satellites, military systems, information systems, and human-rated spacecraft.
cons: In my 5 years with Lockheed Martin, among my scores of engineering colleagues I saw just one engineer promoted, and that was at a more junior level.  Merit increases are an embarrassment, less than the inflation rate.  A broken corporate-wide training tool was deployed which fails to give credit for completed training, then the burden was placed on employees to prove they completed their training.  Not only was an apology not made, this disaster was never even acknowledged, a typical corporate behavior.

review_title: Can get lost in the weeds
job_title: Staff Systems Engineer in Moorestown, NJ
pros: Always leading edge, good pay and benifits, (so far) Lots of supportive co-workers.
cons: LM is a great place to work, provided you dont get into a positon where you dont work directly for your manager. LM is a matrix org. so you can have a functional manager (approves time card, performs reviews, etc) but work for a different project manager. This can lead to a situation where the person who really cares cant do anything for you. Executive Leadership does seem to be more concerned with stock price than employee moral sometimes.

review_title: 9+ years, straight out of colllege... Great start; Great company
pros: Very diverse environment and great place to learn. There is a great work-life balance and flexible hours.
cons: No upward mobility. There is a lot of process and documentation that you must go through to get the smallest things changed, although the processes that needs changing, is to better process improvement.

review_title: Only company that I have worked for that cared about their employees.
pros:
Reliable company where high level management cared as much about their employees as they do their clients/customers and the bottom line. The company adapts well to the changing economic and environment. The lower management is super! Never had a bad thing to say about any of my managers. Of course, all were former military, as I, who knew how to manage.

Perks were as good as the government laws would allow. Many clients also extended significant discounts to LM employees, i.e. Dell, General Motors, etc.

Benefits were as good or better than competitors. Education benefits were great.

Corporate ethics were the same from top to bottom, "High Standards"
cons: As in all BIG corporations there are problems, lay-offs, etc.

job_title: Subcontract Administrator, Senior in Orlando, FL
pros: This company provides wonderful benefits; flexible hours, insurance, etc.  The work environment is currently positive, and the jobs are very stable.  The culture is military-ish, and deadlines are set to be attainable.
cons: After completing multiple trainings and a Master’s degree, this company was un willing to provide more work or more opportunities, had to relocate to achieve that.  This company has too many levels of management, which causes a lot of finger pointing.

pros: Many traditions and yet still evolving.  You will meet many amazing and like minded people.  Majority of my friends,  mentors and professional networks are in,  or in some way (i.e. retired contractor) to the military. A lot of diversity and your favorite people and friends will include those of various ethnic races.  We are all American,  all Soldiers.
cons: The Army is always evolving.  The positive changes it seeks with regards to cutting down on toxic environments in some units is on paper only.

pros:
-Great work life balance
-generous vacation policy
-tuition reimbursement available 
-Overall stable environment
cons: pay is below finance positions in other industries. Additionally, unless you work in financial planning and analysis or a controlloer / corporate type of function - skills may not be easily transferable to other industries outside of government contracting. Another con is that it is very hard to move up - promotions are based almost solely on years of experience. What this leads to is a company full of employees who contribute less than many young, ambitious, and highly effective workers - but still make significantly more simply because of th title acquired through many years of experience.

review_title: Good Company, but not what it used to be.
pros: Corporate benefits, policies, structure and resources allow for one to self-direct and innovate; was able to generate new business through genesis via independent research and development (IRAD) program.  Facility was rich in history and prime location.  Colleagues were brilliant.
cons: Process sometimes kills progress.  Corporate leadership did not understand missions at the facility, and attempted to relocate them in 2013; they subsequently failed miserably to do so and lost most of the intellectual base.

pros: If you are a graduating Senior LM is a great place to start your career.  There are plenty of programs to help launch your career including leadership development programs and leadership clubs.  As your 3rd company you should be more in tuned with what you are looking for and can really take advantage of what the company can offer.  If you are willing to relocate the opportunities are endless for early to mid-career employees.
cons: There is a lot of change occurring and I find that the communication that flows down to the lower levels is inconsistent across the functions.

review_title: Solid pay but very little else for satisfaction.
pros: Compensation is good for the area.  Large corporation with many resources aid in building a professional network.  Opportunities to work in many regions and internationally and to work on some exciting programs.
cons: No investment in employees.  Management incapable of putting employees in a position to be successful.  Employees are commoditized and little value is put on the individual or respecting boundaries.  Very much an old boy network.  Exceptionally wasteful of money especially taxpayer money on government projects which  is seen as 'free'.

pros: Get to work with really smart people who are passionate about what they do.
cons:
Because of security clearances you can sometimes not know exactly what you're going to do until you do it. 
The office space for the majority of the workers at the Sand Lake road plant is just horrible. Packed 6 people into a 3 person cube, and and some of these areas are in a trailer with horrible air flow and a wonky ac unit. 
Not telecommuting friendly at all even though they promote it. 
Parking is a nightmare
Pay is low for engineers compared to similar companies

review_title: Above Average Company to Work For!
job_title: Systems Engineer Associate Manager in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:
A 10% 401K company match is fantastic. Much higher than the industry standard. 

Lots of different opportunities within the company. Management is usually very receptive and helpful when someone is looking for a new position.

Meaningful work that is important.
cons:
Only 5 sick days a year. Get a bad case of the flu, and you could easily be out most of that time.  As a result, people come to work sick, which in turn gets more people sick.

Depending on what Line of Business you work for, salary pay bands can vary by as much as 20%.

Raises are below average, sometimes not keeping up with inflation. Must be top achiever in your salary group to get higher raises, which is not easy.

review_title: Not a bad place for an intern
pros: Great benefits. Some upper management, executives very approachable. Most managers allow flexible work hours. Most managers allow you to charge as many overtime as you want. Very nice relocation stipend. Free VTA like every company in the Silicon Valley. The company really wants you to know more about them. Free food, intern activities. Company policy to ask interns to return for full time positions (you have to really really really mess up to NOT  return as an intern).
cons: Company is still a little bit old school. Horrible horrible cubicles. IT can be a little bit slow to responding your problems. The work atmosphere can be a little more positive.

review_title: It's good work if you can get into the mainstream.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Rockville, MD
pros: The company is huge, and most portions of it, at least for engineers, tend to hold on to you for a while.  It's not like the govt. contracting sector is going away.  Also, they tend to be good about paying for external education, even if getting it internally is hard (due to budget constraints, not lack of availability).
cons: They HATE spending overhead, so good luck finding a Christmas party or anything.  The regular benefits are good, but it's not fun to work here anymore.

job_title: Embedded Software Senior in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Great Products! Where else can you go to design and build 5th generation fighter aircraft? Other than mgrs the people in fort worth are great to work with.  For the most part a very stable well est place to work. If you are a 0-5 year employee they will give you any thing you want to keep you there!
cons: A lot of red tape.  culture clash between 20-30somethings and 50+.  it seems that if a mgr messes up  they promote them and not demote them.   The performance management system is very messed up. your mgr rates you even before you enter your response to your personal objectives.

review_title: Lazy martin is the place to be if you like to sit around and surf the web most of the time
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Good benefits, work/life balance, lots free time at work
cons: Lots of high level 60-80 year old people sitting around doing nothing while collecting a $$$ check.  You'll see people on eBay, solitaire world, or Youtube.  I've received a message on youtube stating "Too much traffic from your IP address, please verify some security info" hilarious!

job_title: Systems Engineer Staff in Marietta, GA
pros: The Benefits are really good.  Working conditions are above average as well as the flex time working the 9/80 work schedule.
cons: Promotional Opportunities don't exist for older workers.  Once you have reached an age level your pretty much have  come to an end for advancement..

review_title: Big, slow, comfortable, many benefits but unexciting
pros: Flexible hours, 9/80 work schedule. Offered pension (N/A now). Coworkers were mostly smart and nice. Interesting projects from big picture perspective. Bicycles for use on campus. 401k and charitable donation matching. Good retention bonus offered for staying on until the end of a project. Occasional BBQ parties, and holiday banquet. Leadership training program and tuition reimbursement. Maybe a good deal when you have a family and work is just a paycheck.
cons: Coming out of college, there weren't many coworkers my age, and most who were talked about leaving. Work never really felt fun. The pace felt slow, with a lot of processes. Projects take years to complete. Few fun perks. Possibly below-average salary. Drab old office buildings.

review_title: If you're not in the good ol' boys club there are no promotions
pros: Good starting salary, good place to learn new skills, good place to learn what it means to be a government contractor
cons: Feel excluded from the decision making process, this place won't promote you fast at all, they value experience over talent, skill, and work ethic. LMCO caters too much to the customer and not concerned enough about their own people. If you work on a production floor expect a union populated by some of the worst people you've ever met.

review_title: The Good, The Bad, and The Very Very Ugly
pros: Very good salary and benefits. Significant projects of national importance. Extremely accomplished, talented and intelligent colleagues. Respected employer.
cons:
Lockheed Martin’s current and long-term business outlook is very poor due to government budget cutbacks. Mostly under the radar, up to 30,000 layoffs have happened in the last several years, and more layoffs are coming. My LM colleagues are looking over their shoulders for the ax; morale is absolutely terrible in Sunnyvale, CA, and likely at most other company facilities. Just last week, LM targeted several new facilities for closure, with another several thousand jobs lost.    

There used to be many development and educational programs available, but most have been cut in the last couple of years (or dried of support), so many fine employees are now left on their own, with little or no support (outside of their manager's advice) in their efforts to advance.

Work/life balance varies wildly, some are lucky to be working a normal and easy 40-hour week. For my first five years, I worked between 55-70 hours a week; my last eight years have averaged 48. Some very senior managers (or those on proposals) work seven days a week, and haven’t had a day off in a year, or more. 

For the last 8-10 years, the company’s mantra has been “We never forget who we’re working for,” urging even more hard work and sacrifice from you, all because the company supports our government and military (which I also strongly do). But, in the end, it’s just propaganda; LM has turned out to be just another company wanting to make money, and (in the words of a company VP) they “will get everything they can from you.” The only things proven to be really important to LM are profits, the shareholders, and the customers buying the products. Those customers end up calling many of the shots in project engineering and management, and on many occasions, they have ruined an engineer's, manager's, Director's or VP's career on a whim or a disagreement, or just a personal issue in a meeting. Employees are disposable to Lockheed Martin; those that are truly valued and respected are rare. Running afoul of a company policy is just fine when the company does it and it benefits the company, but when an employee does it, it's big trouble, and likely termination. I've seen (and heard of this) many times.  

And finally, watch your back with HR – they have a very long history of protecting select people (especially those within HR) who blatantly and frequently break the rules or mistreat their people. For years, I’ve seen far too much wrongdoing (and stood up against what I could - I likely was laid off because of it). LM surely does not want those things coming to public light, so with your (pretty good) severance package comes with a big string and a very strong warning – you saw nothing, and you will say nothing.

review_title: Not as stable as you might think
job_title: Software Engineer Senior Staff in Littleton, CO
pros:
- Awesome scenery at the Deer Creek Facility.  
- Gave me the opportunity to learn AWS cloud technology.  
- Many employees that have worked for LM say that when contracts are terminated, managers were always able to find them new positions in the company.  
- LM employees get free access to Safari books online.  
- The Deer Creek Facility has a decent gym, with free weights, bench press, 4 treadmills, ....  Also has a racquetball court.
- Some programs offer ability to travel overseas (but is not the norm)
cons:
- Big company does not mean stability.   For example, I was hired in 2015, but program was decided to be moved to MD in 2016, so the entire team was threatened to be laid off.  There were about 60 of us.  Now, about 20.  And the deadline is end of fiscal year.   
- Management is the typical political scenario.  They say they care about their employees, but actually don't, or perhaps don't know how to.  For example, Management had no plan on moving employees to new positions before announcing end of program.
- Very slow hiring process.  There's an internal job board, but the process is so slow that response from inquiries take months.
- Got food poisoning from the cafeteria and found several other people also threw up.
- A lot of bureaucracy to get software installed on your workstation.  For example, took 3 weeks to install Notepad++.
- Possibility of losing your clearance.  For example, if you have a TS/SCI clearance, but the project's customer requires a Polygraph, LM will not read you on for your SCI, so you will lose your SCI clearance if you wait for your Poly adjudication for more than 2 years, which is highly likely.  Some employees' clearance was completely removed due to LM security ineptitude.
- Performance evaluation process takes a lot of time/effort out of your day.  A lot of bureaucracy again.
- Weird Paid Time Off (PTO) plan.  2 weeks of vacation + supplemental 1 week vacation + undetermined personal time off that you can take unlimited amount because there's no written rule, but is generally frowned upon if you take more than a week.  You can carry over only 2 weeks vacation to the next year, but can only accrue up to 400 hours.
- Pay is on the low side.  They claim benefits and stability, but that's probably not true.  Medical/dental/vision for employee+spouse+children is about $560/month for premiums.  Not too high compared to other small companies, but since small companies will pay you more than $1,000/month more than your cost of benefits, the LM pay seems a bit low.  If your level of performance is high, you get 1% pay raise.
- Expectations are higher than your pay grade.  For example, management expected a Level 5 engineer to attend symposiums, write patents, publish journals, but his pay was on the level of a senior programmer and he was not given funding to attend symposiums.
- Numerous compliance training requirements.
