job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
Every Friday off is nice. Lockheed with work with even irregular schedules. The company benefits are only okay. 
Work with a lot of smart people
Good as a first job and a resume booster
Job security is a plus
cons:
Lockheed has a culture that believes they only need to compete with other defense contractors as employers. As such, when other defense contractors lower their standards for how they treat their employees, Lockheed will follow suit, including with benefits. Pay is only okay and healthcare is only getting worse. This is terrible for morale and does not keep people at the job. 
Lockheed will communicate when their groups are not able to promote from within, which is good. However, having to actively look for a job for a promotion is awkward. 

Also, depending on the work you do, it can get easy and monotonous. This makes it easy to become complacent and potentially be unmarketable. 

Depending on your work, your manager will be physically distant, and therefore hard to form a relationship. 

Lastly, in a time of crisis, Lockheed treated the outbreak as business as usual with a little hand sanitizer sprinkled in the factory. The factory was pretty much full capacity with no social distancing. People were still crowding in golf carts. Cafeteria was operating at full capacity with no social distancing. Plenty of people operating without masks. It wasn’t until a month of social distancing that Lockheed decided to order masks for those who cannot practice social distancing due to the nature of their job. This does not make people feel safe at their workplace nor valued.

review_title: LMMFC ... not a place for innovation
pros: Right out of college, no experience necessary. LM only hires the brightest, but, the quality of work performed doesn't match the expectations of a new hire. It puts a foot in the door to new engineers. I would say it's a good place to start. But, unfortunately, not a good place to sharpen your skills.
cons: It's not really interesting. there's no design work to be performed, just support. If you're a new hire, you'll be more of a technical secretary in/out of the job.

review_title: LM is your place if you want to be a part of history.
pros: The nature of the work in LM is exciting and very important.  If you really want to be a part of something that makes a difference...LM is the place to work
cons: Heavily bureaucratic...in someways not any more agile or creative than the government.  Very process focused which is contrary to the foundations upon which Lockheed was historically known for.

review_title: Great place to work with many great opportunities for advancement.
pros:
Lockheed Martin is an incredible company to work for.

Vast number of opportunities for promotion and professional growth.  Senior management is very supportive of those personnel with ambition to climb the corporate ladder.  They are often quick and willing to coach and mentor those who demonstrate hard work and dedication. 

Human capital is valued heavily by the organization.  LM invests heavily in the continuous professional development of it's personnel.  So if you're willing to learn, LM is a great source of knowledge!  They offer a vast selection of courses at no charge to employees; some are even offered to family members.

Unlike other companies I've worked for, Lockheed Martin places great emphasis on maintaining healthy, solid relationships with its corporate partners.  From my own experience working on programs where we are the subcontractor of a direct competitor, regardless of the perceived unfairness we were being dealt, we still remained focused on to mission success while maintaining nothing less than complete professionalism based on our very own ethical principles.
cons:
Like most large companies, there are a few managers who can be overzealous at times, feeling the need to "beat their chests" and flex their managerial power in an intimidating and unprofessional manner.  This should neither be accepted nor tolerated by any means!

Some program managers do a poor job in creating and maintaining an inclusive work environment.  This is evident by a lack of communication within certain work groups and teams; often coupled with resentment between members within those groups. 

Benefits aren't as good as they used to be (today in 2012).  But then again, given the current political and economic environment, I understand the need to cut costs to remain competitive.  That doesn't mean I'm happy about my benefits being scaled back.

pros: I like the people that I work with.
cons: The contract I am working under is cheap. There is no room for advancement. They don't help pay for any classes to help improve our knowledge of the software we need to use. The management in my department is horrible. If you liked being talked down to and told that you do everything wrong then it's fine. My hours were cut because of the lack of work they have coming in.

review_title: A good place to grow and learn
pros:
*In the right organization, management is supportive of career and educational development
*It is possible to advance in a rewarding career while maintaining work/life balance; it is expected that employees leave after a 40-hour workweek
*Many opportunities to take other jobs, learn new skills, get involved in special projects
*Continuing education tuition assistance, leadership development/rotational programs
cons:
*Funding uncertainty on programs can occur in the light of government budget problems
*Large defense contractor means bureaucracy that can sometimes be frustrating
*IT security means software and hardware tools available to employees are almost always out of date and limited in options

pros: Good environment to work. Professionals at all levels. Benefits are competitive and generally it is a good place to be.  Good long term place to be with a decent retirement.  Average with the current benefits.
cons: Not competitive.  Poorly organized.  Not cost effective.  Good at huge programs but not flexible enough to compete in the new environment of smaller budgets and shifting requirements.

job_title: Information Systems Analyst for USACE in Kansas City, MO
pros: They look at all their employees where I was employed (USACE-US Army Corps of Engineers), as their family.  If you have a problem or are have a tardiness issue they will do everything to keep you within the company, even adjusting your work hours.  We pretty much made our own schedule within the 8 hr with 1 hour lunch break mandatory policy.  You could come in and leave so long as you didn't break that policy, management had no leg to stand on if they didn't agree with you.  They did many morale boosters, and kept in touch with all of us, we were spread around the globe, and was never overly critical.  They held our hands and stood in the fire on many things so we (their contractors) didn't have to.  They gave us regular pay raises, matched our 401k 100% to our contribution and gave us their VIP status on things like cell phones and stuff on agreements they had with major cell phone companies, online shoe stores, etc.  it was a little like having an expense account.  They took over USACE from another company that I was with.  They carried me over, so I was there about 4 years total.  I appreciated that the workplace was Army related because I am prior Army.  I really loved it there!
cons: Not any.  I left for personal issues.  Am now retired from working, live in TX and take care of my family while going to school.  I wish I were still there, I miss the friends I've made.  But I know I cannot return due to my disability.  That would be the only con.

review_title: Great for up and coming engineers, but not enough opportunities for mid to senior level
pros: Great environment for young engineers to get some real practical experience. Lots of senior folks willing to mentor, and management is very supportive of your career development. Work life balance is also great especially with 9/80.
cons: Due to budget cuts, there is a lot less room to grow for mid level or senior engineers. After years of layoffs of senior positions, the outlook for Sunnyvale  campus is getting more bleak.

pros: Excellent pay - great co-workers; excellent training; great volunteer opportunities;
cons: work-life balance; redeployment efforts; find a way to hold employee clearances so they are not lost when working on projects not requiring that level of classification.

review_title: Big Corporation - Some Good, Some Not So Much
job_title: Aircraft Thermodynamics Lead Engineer in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Fielded systems have reputations of technical superiority, cutting edge combat equipment, highly regarded and well-known.  A large company has lots of opportunities around the world.
cons: Like other large companies there is tremendous inertia and lots of competition for desirable positions.  Company rules are very numerous, but insiders are able to work around the rules which at times feels unfair.

review_title: It has its pros and cons
pros: Flexible work schedule and various interesting projects. Ability to move around due to company size.
cons: Knowledge sharing is lacking. Large experience gap is prevalent throughout the company. Processes often hinder and slow down efficiency drastically in some cases.

pros: Good 401k and CAP if you are lucky enough to get hired under the good ledger. Salary is competitive with other companies. Three weeks vacation plus two weeks of floating holiday, again if on the good ledgers. Good work life balance
cons: Horrible Health plan, not much attention give to new hires. A lot of jealousy exist since many people have effectively pigeonholed themselves and are constantly on edge about being replace. Company does not care about there employees it seems, there one an only goal is to raise the stock price and whatever will do that, they will do.

pros: Numerous locations throughout the U.S. And the world, easy to transfer to different locations, pays for additional education
cons: Don't care about you as an employee, does not pay well, unethical, difficult to get promoted.  I've been working for LM since I graduated college.  I earned two master's degrees (one in engineer, one I supply chain management) during my time, been on an international assignment for 2.5 years, and I'm still a level two.  Do the math!

pros:
Lockheed Martin is one of the most respected engineering companies in the world. Employees take a lot of pride in producing the highest quality product for the warfighter. It is an amazing career experience being exposed to all the different programs and their products/assemblies everyday.

There is a new problem to solve every day on the production floor and there is never a dull moment. There is always plenty of work to do. I like the fact that I am not tied down to my desk all day like some other parts of the engineering world. I am constantly talking to the operators (hourly workers) about how to improve our processes and how to design better tools for them. Manufacturing is a lot of root cause analysis, troubleshooting, and process/efficiency improvement but you still get your fair share of tooling research/design. Although you do not use most of the difficult engineering theories/concepts from school, the job expects you to be a quick learner and problem solver. 

Work/life balance is very important to the company. Pay is what you'd expect being an engineer in Ocala, FL (low cost of living). 

There are so many amazing engineering jobs throughout the company. It seems after being in a role for about 2 years, the company wants you to explore new roles either at the same location or new one.
cons:
Ocala has everything you need, but not the most exciting area for a new college grad. However, you are 1.5 hours from Orlando, Tampa, Daytona, 45 min from Gainesville, etc.. 

Once in a while you are expected to work on off days but you get paid OT which is fair. 

Working with the Union can be annoying and counter productive at times.

pros: Steady, consistent, reliable work.  You always knew what was expected of you when you showed up for work and were trained and certified accordingly
cons: Management had no regard for labor.  Very self-promoting and did not respond to workforce inputs and suggestions for improving site morale.  Rigorous over bearing QA that would'n't let the process detect and clear problems as was done in the past.  Unnecessary due to extremely high reliability rate of our product

pros: 9/80 week,  new Lockheed management. Stable military and government orders. If the S97  Raider and JMR end up proving to work, the future at Sikorsky is bright.  Otherwise, Sikorsky could end up being a one product company eventually, with the CH53K.
cons: Low raises, high turnover in engineering. Knowledge base is declining. Bureaucratic. Commercial helicopter sales are in the tank.

pros:
Great pay
Better than decent management
Communication is pretty good
Individual growth accessible with experience
Tuition assistance
Multiple employee discounts
cons:
High premiums for the health care provider which is absurd for a multi-million dollar company. 
No out-sourced training for OJT exercises approved.

review_title: Why do people fail to wash their hands after using restroom?
pros: Not many. Pension is ending, high deductible medical plans, average vacation time, below average sick time,
cons: Many new appointments of Directors who are not qualified. management needs to learn how to speak to employees, not talk down to employees. Not very advanced in the software tools and too many are homegrown obsolete technology. Lots of people fail to wash their hands after using the restroom - this is down right gross. Paper towel dispensers in restrooms are frequently out of paper so personnel have no way to dry their hands.

review_title: Lockheed Martin - A good place to start but stay aware of your changing situation
pros: LM is a good place to start your career.  Most of my co-workers were exceptionally talented, motivated and team oriented.  I learned a lot from these folks and it was a good foundation for both the technical and business aspects of my career.  The benefits are good and Management is supportive with regard to family and work/life issues.
cons: Some Management teams are a real joy to work with. If you have the good fortune to be on one of these teams you will really feel good about working for LM. But as you go on to different projects be aware that all Management teams are not the same as some can have issues.  When it does go bad you see Management conflicts of interest, ethical issues, glib disregard of employees professional recommendations, advice or warnings, permissiveness in allowing abusive managers to abuse without correction or consequences and ineffectual ethics investigation and enforcement.  This is a big company and in all big companies making changes takes strong positive leadership.  It does exist, but the company needs to do more to cultivate the environment where an employee "doing the right thing" is not abandoned to their own moral courage

job_title: Software Engineer in Valley Forge, PA
pros: The company is not going anywhere.  Easy to get the required resources to do your work, if you are working in an important enough arena.  Company reputation is quite good.  Name recognition is also good.  Generally the level of professionalism is wonderful.  Non-union advancement and pay increases make sense and are mostly fair.  Movement within the company is encouraged.  Starting to more liberally embrace telecommuting and work from home.  Great work life balance.  Good tuition reimbursement 15k/yr for MS.  Many locations throughout the country and world.  Even if your program gets cut, if your are a good employee they can and will find you a position.  Given upcoming percentage of retiring employees (~50% in the next 10 years are at retirement age) career advancement opportunity is very high.
cons: Cumbersome routines and traditions.  Lots of older employees quite set in their ways.  Union tech positions are set up for the average performer as a lifelong job, far too stagnant.  Tech pay is lower than other companies for the same type of work.  General resistance to the value that open source technology can bring to the table.  Percentage of truly incompetent workers that get shuffled or promoted away from their continual failures.

review_title: LM IS&GS has its pluses (like job stability and career growth) but don't work here if salary is most important!
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Reston, VA
pros: Job stability, job satisfaction, career growth, ability to work on new technology, flexible schedule, good vacation policy, one of the few companies with a pension plan, good co-workers, the company has a good reputation and generally is impressive to say you work for Lockheed Martin
cons: salaries are below average in Lockheed Martin's effort to reduce labor rates to the government, Lockheed Martin has been posting record profits lately despite also announcing lower then expected pay raises, despite Lockheed Martin's recent success they have been unable to utilize any profits to help employees with rising health care costs, working for a large corporation often gives the impression that the corporation does not care about the employees, Lockheed Martin's excuse is they are no worse than the average, they tout being just average for benefits and salary as if its attractive to employees rather than trying to be better than the competition like they should be

review_title: Great benefits, flexible work hours, but career advancement is slow and frustrating.
pros: Great benefits, flexible time off, lots of vacation time.  It's a flex-time envirionment, so employees can work their own hours to some extent.  In my experience, management style is mostly "hands off."  The benefit to this is that I get to spend some of my time on what I am most interested in.  Because Lockheed does 98% of its business with government, engineers get to work on some large scope projects, some with far reaching implications which makes the work more interesting.  Lockheed is a massive corporation that has room to for growth into different business areas.  In my experience, management is reasonable flexible in finding the right fit for you within the corporation as long as you express your desires clearly and effectively.
cons:
Management:
Lockheed's hierarchy is a huge mess of managers, program managers, and other kinds of managers.  There isn't much visibility up the management chain unless you are involved in a red project.  In my experience, there seems to be a constant in and out flux of management types into and out of programs.

Growth/Recognition:
My biggest complaint about Lockheed is that it seems very hard to get recognition or growth opportunities for new employees.  There is a big hierarchy already in place and a lot of old guys that are used to doing things a certain way.  This barrier can be overcome, but it is not easy for a new college hire.  I have put in a big effort to move up in my performance rating and felt that my efforts mostly go unnoticed.  I also feel like I can't be as creative as I would like to be because of the line of work that Lockheed does (Integration and Test, Contracting, etc).

review_title: Great career growth, tons of opportunities but limited salary increase and uses of  force distribution.
job_title: Software Engineer Senior in Valley Forge, PA
pros:
The company is big and located all over the US and around the world. This gives an employee the opportunity to choose a different position within the company but at another location. It definitely gives the employee a great potential career growth and tons of opportunities. 

Another reason are the employees of the company. Many of the people I've met and worked with are intelligent, hard workers, and great people to know.  It allows you to build a network if you ever need to contact these individuals in the future.  

For most of the project's I've worked on, the hours are flexible. The mentality is if you need to work 50 hours to get your work completed, then you work your 50 hours. However if you can get it done in 40 hours, then work just 40 hours.  It doesn't have to be 8-5 every day. If you have an appointment in the morning, then you can potentially work 5 hours the first day and make up the other 3 hours on the other days of the week.
cons:
The salary pay can start out high but the salary increase tends to plateau rather quickly. The company also practices force distribution when it comes to performance reviews and salary increases even if all members within a team performs exceptionally.  Although I have not been affect, a few of my colleagues have which is pretty unfair to them. 

Another downside is the being a salaried position, if you need to work an additional 40 hours to get your work done, you need to work those additional 40 hours as overtime. No extra pay. I've been in situations in which they do pay those overtime hours but also in situations in which they have not.

review_title: Doing my second internship at Lockheed Martin
pros: Lockheed Martin is a fast-growing company, with plenty of diverse job opportunities in all sorts of areas, from Procurement to Compliance to Engineering (of course!). A sizeable chunk of its workforce of 140,000 people is retiring within the next decade, and there are going to be many openings to fill when the baby-boomer generation leaves work. While Lockheed's benefits may not be as good as they may have been - mostly because their pension benefits have been eliminated like at most other firms - they still provide a very competitive package along with generous pay. Another reason to work here that may appeal to some people is the opportunity to move around to various offices around the country. With 60+ offices scattered throughout North America (the US and Canada), offices in the UK, and even one in Argentina, there is sure to be a location to match your needs and interests. The people have been very nice and helpful in general, and I find that there seems to be a minimum of backstabbing and other devious behavior.
cons: Like any other large corporation, there are going to be distasteful aspects. One for me has been the sometimes ridiculous amount of time it takes to get people to do things. The bureaucracy can be intense, especially since Lockheed Martin has to abide by so many government rules, regulations, and restrictions. For example, getting a very basic security clearance took weeks if not months, along with me having to fill out piles of paperwork and an EXHAUSTIVE life summary. I'm surprised that anyone can remember that much information, and the only reason I was able to is because I've kept detailed records of my employment history and other things. Another somewhat annoying aspect has been staying busy at all times. It sometimes seems that everyone is too busy to really sit down and talk with the interns. However, to give the issue justice, everyone probably IS really busy, and there sometimes is a good level of fun and games in the office that helps liven up the mood and keep everyone friendly.

review_title: Lockheed Martin provides you with the right tools, and it's up to you how to use them.
pros: There is a great deal of room for advancement, but you really have to make the most of it given the tools and resources given to you. Management is great and the assignments are great.  Working in a large organization is great because there is funding available for training and for traveling for meetings or conferences.  There are rotation programs where you can try out different positions within the company for 6 months to a year.  It's a nice way to get out there and find your nitch.  Once you've found a place that's right for you, the opportunities are limitless.
cons:
If you like the defense industry, then this is the place for you.  If you are not into defense, but like space-related projects (like satellites and Research and Development work) then this place is also for you.  If you don't like any of these things, you may not enjoy working for LM.  Some of the downsides is that, like any normal business in this industry, there are a lot of old ways of doing things... so if it's not broke, don't fix it.  This is very typical of LM at times.  It's only when there is R&D work that new technology comes out to replace the old.

Working for a large corporation could also have its downsides.  Yes, there is a great deal of growth opportunity, but that just means you have to work that much harder to get yourself noticed.  You also have to be careful with office politics.  Not to mention, the work that you do is very much government oriented so it also sometimes means that things are really slow and then really fast.  Sometimes programs could be cut just out of the blue.  So, it's a tough industry but it is definately fun if you're into the hi-tech stuff.

review_title: Job Description and pay are two separate things at Lockheed
job_title: Senior Member Engineering Staff in Moorestown, NJ
pros: Good People. Competitive benefits like most large companies. There is an engineering union called ASPEP that gets a higher raise for their employees and some additional benefits. Like I said, the benefits are not the bestest but just competitive with other large corporations except for the added union benefits. There is flexible work schedules that can be negotiated with your management. Pleasant work environment. Work is diverse. I think career advancement must be an obsession for the employee if one wants to advance in the company. It will not be given and there are maturity rules and requirements to get promoted in the union for engineers.
cons: Focus is on full spectrum leadership throughout the ranks. Senior management emphasizes diversity, but the makeup of the departments show clearly that minorities have a glass ceiling. Their technical director group all comprise of white males and females - There is almost no chance of a minority getting a position in this group. Some of my friends have tried but were turned away because of maturity reasons. There are many minorities at the team lead level, and some at FLM level. Not sure why this is the case, just based on observations. No Asian minorities at the senior management level. This company also has a bias with military academy graduates as oppose to civilian college graduates in management positions. All AEGIS related work only.

pros: Ethical culture, emphasis on work-life balance, opportunity to engage in a variety of learning experiences.  I'm most proud of the community orientation -- the emphasis on volunteerism, the money the company invests in basic research with a variety of universites, and the real contributions toward K-12 science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) education.
cons: The company is shrinking now, partly due to externalities and partly due to a lack of substantive actions on long-term strategic sustainability issues.  It is a generally unpleasant work environment.  I hope that this will improve as the economy improves, but right now I see nothing more than lip service toward strategic issues:  more agile product development, workforce development, or addressing competitors and new entrants to the market.   Company appears to be following the path of  "How the Mighty Fall" as Jim Collins describes.  Diversity initiatives fall flat.  Serious pay equity issues abound.  HR is a broken organization - it does not act as a strategic partner to the business.  Instead,  the HR organization makes arbitrary nonsensical decisions, is a barrier to hiring appropriately to the business needs, and retaining the right people.

pros: Flex hours, plenty of vacation from the start.  401k with a good match, people are great to work with.  Lots of extra benefits including gym reimbursements, discounts at local restaurants, and company intramural leagues.  Yearly raises unless you are severely under performing.
cons: Very hard to move around right now.  Seems that high performers are punished and forced to stay on same projects because they are deemed valuable.  Promotions are hard to get.

review_title: Talking the Talk, rarely Walks the Walk.  Mimics the stereotype of govt.
pros:
1. Benefits - exist and are adequate 2. Pay is remarkably high for meeting  relatively low expectations
3. Flexible work hours is nice
4. If you want to be left alone for years on end, this might be the place for you
5. Company is huge
6. Still has a 401k program (mediocre choices though)
7. Online IT support for desktops is actually quite good and responsive (compared to my previous employer which manufactured them)
8. Ethics hotline remains confidential. (I've tried it twice. Got no satisfaction either time but I wasn't ratted out either)
cons:
1. If you weren't prior-military working on this particular program, you'll always be an outsider (I've been here 7 years and am still very much an outsider). It's populated with retired military on both contractor and govt sides who have always known (and sometimes always hated) each other.

2. Atmosphere is decidedly non-collegial.  When seeking out information from another person you will be greeted as if you are probably an enemy who will cause more work or some trouble for that person. Phone calls aren't returned, email conversations end after 2 exchanges maximum. (1 if exchanging with Finance.) Generally unfriendly atmosphere.

3. Meetings rarely begin with introductions and it's easy to be sitting in a meeting and discover 20 minutes in that you are in the wrong meeting! (at least for the first few years)

4. The overhead associated with accomplishing anything at all is staggering. One example is the performance evaluation system- Goals for the calendar year must be turned in by the end of March and results turned in by  mid-October so as to give "the system" time to process the inputs. This means your heroic sacrifices for the company during the major holiday periods will go unreported and you're being cheated out of 6 months of evaluation because the HR system overhead is so slow.
  
5. Internally developed systems for dispatching help or reporting broken stuff is slow to non-functional. If you really need something, you need to know  who does the work and go see them directly. Bring donuts and all will be well.

6. Training consists entirely of "compliance training." This is annual repetition of such things as how to fill out your timecard, what constitutes conflict of interest, export controls, workplace harassment, and all the hot-button HR stuff that a govt contractor has to do.   Actual work-related training courses are listed in the catalog but never held, or never held where you can attend. You can earn another university degree - on your own time of course if you want some training.

7. Conversation with management is decidedly one-way. This is where the Talk is Talked. There are efforts made to have "skip level" communication sessions with 2nd level and higher management but no trust has been earned beforehand so one must pick one's words with great care.  I never attend these sessions because I fear that once I got started that I'd be leaving the very same day (note all my Con  points ).  They aren't hard to avoid - they are scheduled once a year en masse.

8. Social engagement tools are advertised by the company recruiters but they have decayed into "info wanted" postings from the business capture folks.  No honest, meaningful dialog is happening because of likely negative consequences. No resemblence to newsgroups or usenet.

9. I expect this will be my last job before I retire to rounding up shopping carts at Wal-Mart because  my  pre-LM job skills have atrophied and I have gained little that's marketable but Office 2000 Excel skills in return. (yes, the company tools are antique)

review_title: OK place to work if you want to limit yourself to the aero, defense, or homeland security industry.
pros: Was OK as entry level with some opportunities to take on challenging work although often work senior employees were too busy or too lazy to accomplish
cons: Unless you have skill/education/experience that is truly portable across industries, the name looks good on a resume but may be hard to trade on when moving on.  In other words, you may find yourself stuck in the aero/defense environment. Not good when Fed budget flatlines or goes down which it will over the next several years.

review_title: At time you feel like just another warm body, but there are pockets of really cool technology.
pros: They have great benefits and there are many challenging problems to solve.
cons: The company would typically rather buy innovation than create it themselves.

review_title: For me it's been good, but others have not been as lucky.
job_title: Senior Staff Systems Engineer in Littleton, CO
pros: If you're into doing spacecraft and defense products, LM has one of the best portfolios of these sorts of things. It's a large diverse company and if you're interested in moving around to different projects then that opportunity is there (but you have to make it happen for yourself). If you're truly a superstar (top 1%) you'll be treated well -- but you still won't rise as fast as you would at a smaller company.On the other hand -- you don't have to work too hard. You can put in the standard 40-hour week and still be considered a good performer. So if you've got other things in your life than work it's nice in that regard.
cons: The current "affordability" climate means promotions are almost nonexistent and raises are paltry. Don't take a job thinking you'll get promoted within a few years -- your manager might want to do it but his hands are tied by HR and central management. The raises are about in line with inflation -- so not really raises. The new health plan is expensive! The glossy brochures make it sound great, but here's the summary: If you're married with kids, expect to pay $3000/year in premiums. If your family remains in perfect health all year, then that's all you'll pay.  But of course that doesn't happen. Factor in some kid office visits for colds, some parent visits for this or that, or even one emergency room or urgent care visit and you'll be out of pocket another $3000. So budget for $6000/year for health care. It *is* capped -- so the $6k/year is the max you'll spend. And you can choose just about any doctor you want.  But that's about the only good news.

review_title: Very little passion or knowledge of the world outside of the defense contractor "bubble"
job_title: Software Engineer in King of Prussia, PA
pros: Work life balance!  Everyone leaves the office exactly when they hit 40 hours (unless they are getting paid overtime).  In fact, your manager will often need to give you APPROVAL to work over 40 hours.  Alternate schedules like 9/80, or 4/10 are often approved without much hassle.
cons:
It's very hard to find employees who actually care about software development at LM, even those who do care tend to have very little knowledge of anything remotely modern.  

"What is an 'XML File'?" - Anonymous "Senior Staff" Software Engineer

It's not uncommon to work on 10 year old workstations running Windows 2000.  The company has an absurd amount of process and seemingly limitless red-tape but there are no real best practices or meaningful standards for software development.

At a high level it doesn't seem like the company even acknowledges software exists despite pumping out millions of lines of it.

Salary is middle of the road, and it's very hard to quickly move up the ladder due to strict minimums for different job titles.

LM is an incredibly bloated organization, there are layers and layers of management who seem to have no real responsibility.  It's very likely your manager will be completely disconnected from you and your work.  This is great for people who want to "coast by", but is very frustrating for top performers.

It's a fine place to work for a few years to kickoff a career, but make sure you leave before you are robbed of your passion.

review_title: Worst place to work for young engineers
job_title: Senior Mechanical Engineer in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
1. Compared to other aerospace companies, LM paid higher initially, but then they rip you off big time later
2. If you know how to do something good, you'll be doing it a lot more, and you ain't moving out of that position anytime soon either
3. If you don't know how to do something, just act busy and you'll be promoted to manager very quickly
4. Your performance evaluation has nothing to do with your performance.  They already know how much they're going to give you, so putting the min. or go extra and above makes no different
5. Learn how to tell good jokes and eat lunch with the boss because that's the only way to move up at LM... it has nothing to do with how much you know.
6. Incompetent people move up really fast in management track
cons:
1. Incompetence people are in manager positions
2. Positions are broken up into smaller chunks, so they can bill the government more (unethical).  This is why defense contracts are always over budget and late.
3. Since you don't get to do what an engineer is supposed to be doing, you are not utilizing your jobs skill at all; eventually you become obsolete, and you can't go work anywhere else because you already lost all of your engineering skills.
4. Don't ever show them that you can do the work for half/quarter of the time because that means they have to show the government that they are efficient, which means less money next contract around... You'll work yourself out of your own job.  Innovation and efficiency are prohibited at LM because that's not their business model.  Their business model is to milk the GOVT' as much as they can, so if you try to save money for the company you're hurting their bottom line (young engineers make this mistake a lot)

pros: Great work experience, challenging assignments with major organizational impact, smart coworkers, all right pay and benefits. The 9-80 schedule is maybe the best perk of all, every other Friday off, and given the workload if it was the other way (8 hours a day 5 days a week) I would still be working 9 hours a day, the off Friday is amazing!
cons: Difficult to advance without moving locations or spending years in same role, pay is locked into a scale, surge periods with a lot of overtime. Sequestration.

pros:
There is a real disposition to work/life balance.  Flexible hours are the norm.  That said, if you get the wrong management crew you might be under pressure to work long weeks - but at flexible times.  It certainly is of value when raising a family.

Salary is good.  Company is becoming extremely cheap ("the new reality"!) but they do keep promises.  And they make a strong effort not to lay people off.

There is an encouragement towards diversity of workforce and diversity of thought.  Managers are generally well-trained and have good perspective beyond the crises of the day.
cons:
There is not a particular bent towards software development.  It shows.  You need to go through layers of process to as much as download a free IDE onto your PC.  We're frequently the opposite of tech savvy (not sure if there is a term).  A mania towards security, combined with layers of beauracracy on purchasing or even downloading software tools, does discourage innovation.

The company is full of older workers desperately trying to hang on - and do any job - long enough for their pension to kick in.  Major topics of conversation ere are early retirements and whether individuals will survive long enough to get their pensions - not solving problems and creating things.

There is not an effective base for software management where I work.  I've seen high-profile efforts run badly by "manager"s who have no real life experience, and who flounder and cause chaos.  This company knows how to build many things, but not so much software.

review_title: Good learning Experience, but they treat you like dirt
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Moorestown, NJ
pros: I learned a lot there. there were great people to work with, but they don't know how to treat engineers (Moorestown, NJ).  I wish the engineers there the best.
cons: Join us, and become member of the Borg.  Government spending going in right direction.  They pay less than average for 'job stability', but the jobs aren't stable anymore.

review_title: Good place to intern in the beginning, but they slowly forget about you after a couple of months

Unchallenging work
Underutilized
Average Work Experience (could be better)

pros: Opportunities to contribute to national defense and the safety of US soldiers. Positions in growth areas can be rewarding with opportunities to work with sharp and dedicated engineers.
cons: Lockheed is contracting right now and many of its programs are winding down so it is not able to offer as many opportunities to work on cutting-edge engineering as it once did. As a publicly traded company, its first priority is to its stock-holders rather than to its employees.

review_title: Good Company with many opportunities for work
pros:
Lockheed has many opportunities for different types of work.  If you've got the ability then they will have opportunities to work.  Most positions have a very flexible work schedules.  For being a large corporation they try to make sure employees feel valued.

Available work within Lockheed core locations are plenty
cons:
It's still a corporation and employees can easily fall through the cracks if they work outside of LM facilities.  
Available Work outside of Lockheed core locations are sparse.

job_title: Pricing Analyst in Fort Worth, TX
pros: You'll be given a lot of responsibility and opportunity to learn early on. Benefits are unmatched (flex time and every other off-Friday, for example).
cons: Government contractor so the goal at the end of every day is to reduce the cost to the customer. Day-to-day this means working in close quarters with your peers in out-dated cubicles.

review_title: Old defense company making honest attempt to be new
job_title: Software Engineering Specialist in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: The compensation is fairly good.  There are some good managers who do communicate,and most of the engineering tools are OK.
cons: There is a need to streamline the design and development processes; when this has happened, it has been uneven.  Opportunities to move to new roles are limited.  There is uncertainty in the overall future of the Sunnyvale facility. There are many times when long hours are required.

pros: Great products, good benefits, most of the people are great and want to act as a team that pulls together
cons: Employee moral is low. there people that believe backstabbing is the way to achieve success. Healthy competition is good and encourages top performance but throwing your co-worker under the bus drags the company as a whole. Management seems to ignore it. Some areas take advantage of the authority they are given and abuse it.

job_title: Usability Engineer Lead in Washington, DC
pros: Lockheed Martin is probably like most US government contractors.  They care a lot about the mission.  There is a lot of potential to change careers within the company or to advance.  There is also a lot of potential for training.
cons: Being that it is a very big company, there is a lot of oversight, which can be good and bad.

pros: Good pay, flexible hours, some telecommuting available. Depending upon the particular Lockheed Martin company involved, some of the projects can be quite interesting to work on.
cons: Slow moving due to the nature of the business and the customer. Individual job experiences may vary depending on management. Many "Software Engineers" cannot write code, but are paid as much as those who can. Training dollars are exceedingly scarce. At my work location, we need to dump our own trash.

pros: Really big company, this may allow you to transition into another role. Access to a wealth a resources (at least for the technical/engineering employees) for continuous learning. Benefits are pretty good with 401k matching up to 4%.
cons: Raises, I have had 2 performance reviews/raises and neither was over 2%. So get a good salary upfront and hope for the best after that. From what I have seen promotions are also hard to come by.  Some employees may be stuck at certain level for a long time.

job_title: ESH Engineer Staff in Herndon, VA
pros: If you want to gain skill in a SME area you don't have yet and are willing to start at the bottom to learn something, you just might.  Just keep raising your hand because you will likely be the only doing so.
cons: ESH is still trying to create a universal management system without purchasing one that works for auditing its various facilities--it's not working. Severe cuts and lay-offs in 2016 resulting in the sale of it's Information Systems Division(675 lay-offs) and projected 1500 lay-offs in 2016-17 within it's MST-Mission Systems & Training Division. If you get hired or work of Space Systems, you may still have a job in 2018.  A serious disconnect between recruiting or talent acquisition and management creates a dysfunctional hiring process for candidates--you never really know where you are at or why/if you have not made the down-select. Salary-base for entry-level 3 ESH is 17% below national averages. There may be out-sourcing of SME ESH areas in the future. Not a safe place to play to launch a career and be there 10 years later....move on!  Lots of dead wood at level 5/6 and above that is not Leadership material but got promoted anyway, who simply uses and then, discards talented ESH professionals. Sikorsky, who was purchased by Lockheed in 2016, had a mass exit of ESH Professionals in late 2015 and early 2016 voluntarily and will likely either move ESH people over from other sectors of LMCO or hire entry level but not Senior Staff. There's a hiring freeze in place for most non-essential skill sets in 2016.

pros: Fantastic group of people to work with, highly dedicated and willing to go the extra mile to ensure program success. Very motivated to prove they are able to take on additional assignments.
cons: Communication could be a challenge as the program was managed across different locations and had several components that needed to be centralized.  Talented managers were let go in order to come in at or better than the cost that was budgeted.

pros: Very smart people and great programs.
cons: If you are a white male you WILL be discriminated against. I was a manager - I saw the "goals" of increasing the numbers of women and "minorities" in hiring, retention and promotion. You WILL see far less competent women and minorities promoted ahead of you. They have numerical goals! And who is the only category who is not a woman or a minority? You guessed it. Straight-up racist/sexist discrimination.

pros:
The 9/80 work schedule (9 hr/day M-Th, every other Friday off) is a major plus and keeps a lot of people around. 
Because Lockheed Martin is so big, there is a lot of opportunity to learn about the defense industry. There is a wealth of knowledge among many employees who have worked at Lockheed for a long time, and Lockheed does a good job of not overwhelming new candidates in my experience.
There are a lot of growth opportunities, and there is an increased emphasis in diversifying the experiences of the employees. 
Lockheed Martin is a company that prides itself on integrity, and that is evident in the way that it treats its employees and how it conducts business. 
If you are interested in learning about and being a part of the defense industry, Lockheed Martin is a great company to work for. My experience with management has been positive, and I have seen an effort toward empowering decision making toward the lower levels of management.
cons:
It is hard to see your role in the grand scheme of things. Lockheed Martin's products are complex and most of the functions are very removed from the actual product. 
Lockheed Martin is a very large and bureaucratic company. While I mentioned that there is an effort to drive decision making down to the lowest levels, this is a slow process and there is still a long way to go. 
Lockheed Martin can only lean out its processes as much as its customer allows. This is still a very risk averse industry, and having the government as a customer means that things go slower.
Finally, Lockheed Martin is a defense contractor. While I'm proud to work for such an impressive company and feel that we do our work with integrity, I do feel disconnected from the customer as someone who has no affiliation with the military. The slogan "We never forget who we're working for" is very accurate - this is a very military-minded company, even in its pursuit of more commercial business.

review_title: They strive to be cutting edge.

review_title: Great place for new college grads

review_title: LM is a very large company struggling until the F35 takes full shape.  In the meantime profits will be thru cost cuts.
job_title: Benefits Dropping Like Your 401K In 2008, Cost Cutting to the Bone in Aurora, CO
pros: I am proud to work for LM in support of US national defense.  It is an ethical place to work and they support a work life balance.
cons:
They are in a battle to contain costs with pay and benefits suffering.  If you are going for a Corp job you may be OK but on a specific program they are fierce about containing cost.  

HR Compensation team will try to low ball you, never accept their first offer.  Pay for performance looks more like a cost of living increase ~2%

My division, IS&GS had aggressive growth and profit goals in 2009, they did not meet them so the first thing they do is cut employee morale events and the Christmas party.  Thanks, our program was in the black but we still have jobs right?  Well then they announce they eliminated vacation buy, a major perk for newer employees.  Then they rollout a corporate healthcare plan with mandated maximum program funding, the result was my healthcare premium jumped 60% and thousands higher in deductable.  I am happy to have a job, but when times are tough, LM has chosen to stick it to their employees.

It seems that management has put the priority on profit margin at the expense of the people.  Good thing LM was able to buyback at least 14M shares (worth a total of about $1B) and raise the dividend this year.  I do not believe a company can sustain performance if they do not invest in their employees.

pros: Lockheed Martin offers reasonable benefits and good work life balance. The company has offices in virtually every major city in the country, which enables employees to relocate rather easily.
cons: Salaries and pension benefits vary between various divisions. For instance, the IS&GS Civil Division has no pension plan and salaries are about 20% lower than other divisions. This results in a high level of employee attrition in the  IS&GS Civil Divsion.

review_title: Take the good with the bad
pros: Lockheed Martin has an incredible selection of interesting projects to work on.  There are exciting and cutting edge opportunities to take advantage of.  The jobs themselves can be really great and the pay is competitive.
cons:
There seems to be a disconnect between management and the employees.  While the engineers work diligently to develop, integrate and deliver amazing capabilities to the customer; managers seem to travel from meeting to meeting with the rare interaction with the employees.  The work is accomplished and overseen by the engineers while managers crunch the numbers and go to meetings.  With this disconnect it seems like a gamble that the managers would ever make really well-informed and good decisions for a project.  If they don't know what the employees do day-to-day how are they to make decisions that impact the projects?  There is a constant murmur that one hand does not know what the other is doing.
There is also the false push for work-life balance.  There is no such thing.  Management has signed the programs up for such aggressive schedules that they preach work life balance then ask you to work the weekends and holidays.
Finally, there is a lot of good-ol-boy practices that happen.  There are high-level engineers that do nearly nothing and get awards and recognition because they run in the right circles.  It really detracts from motivation.  
If it were not for the exciting work and good pay; I would not be at this company.

review_title: Great Company to start a career with

cons: May not be the most workforce oriented company, you kind of get the feeling the people are not as important as meeting schedules at least in the production parts of the company I've worked in. And layoffs happen a little more often then most in my opinion

review_title: Great work, but under valued employees
pros: Work is challenging and often exciting depending on which contract you work on.  Offer tuition reimbursement so you can get your master's degree for free or close to it.  Great 401K match.
cons: Pay is somewhat low.  Can be hard to advance and even if you do senior level work, they will not promote you unless you meet the minimum requirements.

review_title: Overall, a great company. Promotions, salary grades, etc...depend heavily upon location

cons: Also work with some people that have been allowed to "skate" along and are clueless but hold very high positions. Depending on location, pay raises and promotions can be great or non-existant. No consistancy.

pros: Some parts of Lockheed treat their employees very well, very good Ethics department, overall benefits very good
cons:
Lockheed is a very fractured company and i am sure people reading about Lockheed are confused when they read reviews at web sites like this one.

Lockheed divisions have different work weeks, pay bands in other works the Salary grades are standardized but the actual high and lows for the same cities can vary 15%.

Work week varies, holiday schedule, amount of money you contribute to the health plan as well as the actual plan.

Pay for performance merely  means you will probably get more than the guy that performs less

however they do force managers to put all their employees into groups poor good better best so someone has to be in the poor group pretty much no matter what.

Managers are overworked some have 30+ employees to manage in addition to an actual job, plus now managers have to manage employees user accounts and new hires.

The current process for reviews LMCommit is roundly hated by everyone but especially managers for them to do their job right for every employee would take weeks of unpaid work.

review_title: Looking Back at Lockehhed Martin Aeronautics Company
job_title: Aersopace Engineer (Software-algorithms) in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
Lots of holidays and vacation - At least 10 days Christmas break each year; get 4 weeks with 5 years and beyond.

Very competitive pay for Dallas-Fort Worth area of Texas - Beat out similar companies in the vicinity.

Relatively manageable work load - Not that many occasions for overtime; up to 2011, overtime requests were readily granted if there was a dire need and can be proven so.

Comparatively good team work - Team members tend to stick together and look out for each other; also share technical information without overly guarding "trade secrets".

Reasonable 401K savings plan and a funded pension plan for those who joined before 2006 and had 5  or more years with company.
cons:
Big , bureaucratic style of management, almost government-like, top-down communications, seldom chances for worker-bees to speak out or appeal unfair supervisory or project decisions. Assumption is that management is "almost always right".

Hard to obtain information on clerical and support staff due to big bureaucracy.  Takes a long time to receive support in terms of office maintenance and travel orders. Middle to upper management approval always needed for most matters, supervisors cannot have say-so in lots of important decisions. 

Old boys network, promotions nowadays if you meet the criterion of "who you know and not what you know"; hard work does not make a significant difference, even though one receives a bit more compensation on an annual performance review basis; promotions to senior or managerial levels requires Engineering VP approval. Old days before F-35 start-up in 2002 were fairer with annual increment process that accumulates merits each year toward promotions.

Difficult to obtain transfers - "who you know" invariably gets you places. Good luck if it is not "who you know" but trying to do it with "what you know"!

Be careful of certain people who show biases and at times even prejudice against others who are not U.S. born or hold differing opinions; can be ultra-hawkish and cling to one-sided strong opinions.

Unionized labor workforce - hire relatively few janitors who may be overworked; less than clean bathrooms.

Few offices with privacy, open bay arrange by cubicles with 4-feet partitions (don't talk too loud over the telephone, or socialize by talking too much and loudly.

Eliminated reimbursements for continuing education courses - Must apply for degree programs in Engineering , MBA, etc., to get reimbursed. Poor performance with bad grades at school result in refusla to reimburse.

Charge $'s for using company operating gymnasium and pool, etc.

Could increase allowance per person company pays for annual Christmas luncheon (only $20).

job_title: Procurement Representative Associate in Fort Worth, TX

job_title: Quality Engineer Senior in Grand Prairie, TX

pros: I've worked with many in leadership positions in Mission Systems and Training and to a great extent, they mean what they say about having integrity and delivering the right results for the customer. Schedule depends on the manager; mine gives me the autonomy and flexibility I need to run my job and my life without second-guessing.
cons: Definite ethos of "pay your dues". Promotions are slow, and opportunities for promotions are rare, mainly due to the current lack of overall unit growth. Not easy to switch units either.

review_title: Great place to start your career, ok place to work if you have lots of ambition and want to go places
pros:
Lockheed Martin is a great place to start your career.  There are plenty of opportunities to learn and grow and the company places an emphasis on training and career development.  The people are for the most part friendly and people are always willing to mentor if you need help and guidance early on in your career.  

In terms of benefits, Lockheed Martin's benefits are above average but are not as good as they used to be.  One of the selling points used to be the pension program but now that that program no longer exists Lockheed Martin is not as attractive as it used to be.  However, there are other areas where the benefits are pretty stellar.  For instance, the company provides a generous tuition reimbursement program that will enable most people to get Masters or PhD degree without incurring any out of pocket expenses.  Also, the company reimburses for a gym membership up to $250 per year. 

Work/life balance is second to none.  Some people will complain about working a lot of hours, but I don't feel like there was ever any pressure to be in at work every weekend.  I know companies like SpaceX definitely have a stronger work ethic and there is more pressure to put in 60-70 hour weeks than at Lockheed Martin.  The saving grace if one does have to work a lot of hours is that overtime is paid after the first five hours.  LM also follows a 9/80 schedule which is nice if you need to get errands taken care of.
cons:
As my review title states, LM is a great place to start your career, but it is hard to advance once you get to the Senior Level (roughly 7-10 years after a Bachelors degree).  Promotions are incredibly hard to come by after that period and there is no guarantee you'll get ahead even if you are a superstar.  This is due mostly to the fact that LM has gotten top heavy and there are too many experienced engineers taking up positions that should be available to younger more talented engineers.  Unfortunately, Lockheed Martin allows this complacency to happen and the company makes no provisions to push out mediocre engineers who aren't deserving of their jobs.  I've been held back promotions twice due mainly to the fact that my boss said my group was too top heavy.  You know a company isn't a good company to work for when your boss specifically states that the only way to get ahead is to leave and come back later.

Another thing that really stinks about LM is that they have this problem with having "too many cooks in the kitchen".  LM should be a lot leaner but as I said before, they are a bloated organization that refuses to get rid of underperforming engineers.  What ends up happening is that there isn't enough work to go around, and charge numbers can be hard to come by.  I've had to taken vacation time before because I didn't have a charge number.  Also, because work is so hard to come by, what ends up happening is that people make a career out of a task that should take a shorter amount of time.  LM is notorious for people working on a task for months on end just so that they have a charge number when the reality is that they should finish the task in a short period of time and move on.  

I also really hated the negativity that surrounded this company.  When I was there, people would complain on a regular basis about the flawed performance management system and how they would get passed over for promotions time and time again.  I don't blame a lot of these folks but none of these people ever made the effort to actually leave the company.  If you want to get ahead sometimes you have to leave your cushy job and jump into a world where you have to prove yourself again and possibly be uncomfortable for a while.  Sometimes that is the only way you can get ahead.  Complaining daily about being passed over for a promotion doesn't help.

Talented engineers end up either as managers at LM or they leave LM all together and find better jobs.  The rest of the crowd is content with having a job and as a result they underperform.  If you like working with mediocre people who are negative than LM is great but if you want to do things with your life and make a difference then I would suggest working elsewhere after you've had your initial experience.

Finally, I appreciated my time there but not so much my management.  I'm sure this isn't true about every group but my managers were some of the worst people I've ever worked under.  It doesn't take much to hold a regular staff meeting or all hands so that your employees know what is going on.  Also, when a valued employee leaves your group, make an effort to attend their lunch or to do something nice for them.  Sadly, none of this happened and as a result, I never want to work for the company again.  That is fine, though.  I am much happier to work for a "new space" company and watch LM wither away like GM and Chrysler did in the Automobile industry.  All hail companies like SpaceX!

job_title: Senior Customer Trainer in Fort Benning, GA
pros:
Great Pay and Benefits
Flexible Schedule

pros:

-LM is great if you're on the right contract. I did not have that fortune.

I wish my manager had been more transparent about the client's management style so they/I could have found a better fit. My colleagues are all highly educated (multiple graduate and terminal degrees), all with over 10 years experience, and our supervisor (client) managed us as though we were recent college graduates- hence,  VERY low office morale. 

- I wish LM had more opportunities for staff who work on client-site interact with the corporate office- even if it meant after-hours networking, training sessions. I felt a real disconnect because I was on the client site 5 days a week-- and a client who made us move mountains if we wanted to attend a out-of-office training, workshop, etc- even when relevant to work. When it came time to looking for a new assignment, I was at a disadvantage. 

- They require you to enter your previous salary when completing the application. I don't know how you get around this required field.  I was offered just a couple thousand above my previous salary-- which was a severe low-ball considering the GS equivalent of my position (which I later learned). Seriously low-balled. I needed the job at the time, so I was not in a position to push back. 

-The economy was at it's worst at the time, so I stayed longer than I should have. I knew in the first 7 months, this was a no-where position. Live and learn.

(excuse any typos)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Some of the departments are great - allowing flexible schedules, trusting employees, providing training so you can grow in your career across the company
cons: Some departments are the exact opposite of described in pros, feeling like you have stepped back into the 1940s with gender and racial inclusion, "old boys network," having face-time be more important than work product, etc. It all depends on the specific manager. If your manager believes in development, you can get training, growth assignments and a career champion that you will not get if your manager sees training you as a threat. If everyone who leaves a department is willing to lateral out, & then they get promoted quickly if they are lucky enough to get to another department, senior management doesn't see this as a red flag

pros: The company invests a lot into employee health and wellness.  They try to get involved into the communities in which they have facilities, fostering a we work  and live here attitude.
cons: Manufacturing has little chance of upwards mobility and meaningful interaction with the higher ups outside of a yearly review and when they come down for trouble shooting.  Management makes decisions directly impacting manufacturing without employee input and couldn't care less afterwards unless something terrible happens.

pros: Opportunities exist for Long term employment.  Leadership programs for fast tracking young engineers with desirable qualifications. Benefits are good.  Flexible hours to accommodate work/life balance.  Mentor programs to help inspire and grow young talent.
cons: Losing talent to companies with more opportunities for higher paying jobs.  Many senior personnel have been retiring due to pension program termination causing some issues with losing knowledge and depth of experience in some areas.

review_title: Lockheed Martin IS Management, Management IS Lockheed Martin
pros: Interesting work, HR works quickly (at least when they are laying you off), great perks if you get into management (a big if).
cons: Use of bait and switch tactics for new hires, constant focus on managers, including the company’s insistence on calling all of them “leaders”. Managers who kiss up to their superiors at the expense of rank and file employees. Lion’s share of resources allocated for management (training, computers, facilities, travel), difficult to get into management if you’re not one of their “Golden Boys”.

review_title: Good place for high-level electronics assembly.
pros:
Good benefits, nice people, exciting to be at a company where you build things that go offworld.

Lockheed also has a flex-time schedule that allows you to be pretty flexible with your time. Clear things with management, you can tradeoff time to do pretty much whatever you need, provided you still hit your minimum hours.
cons: Pace can be pretty slow; you can be left waiting for training or for work, or for supplies. Assembling items at class 3 will mean hand-intensive processes; whereas other non-space businesses would employ more technology.

review_title: Lockheed Martin has a leadership development program
job_title: IS LDP in San Francisco, CA
pros: The Information Systems Leadership development program allows for rotational job assignments, corporate training events, and 100% tuition reimbursement.  I've only been with one business unit, but the management I'm under is very competent.  My managers are retired Army officers.
cons: They say the pay is competitive, but I think it's about average within the industry. As always, contract work has it's down falls (i.e. contract re-compete, reduction of funds, etc.)

review_title: Its Time For A Changing Of The Guard
pros: Relatively decent pay (Make sure you get your money up front, don't rely on promises of bonuses).  It's a huge organization so opportunities to move "laterally" somewhere else are available (if you have a connection)
cons:
Similar to what others have stated, promotions are far and few between.  LM is a very top heavy organization.  Most Senior Management/Directors and VP's have been with the company for 10 - 15 years at least.  They tend to stick with a core group of people to form their "inner circle".  Most senior managers and VP's don't leave the company for a while so these positions don't come around often.  When they do, it seems that those that are "in line" for the promotions get them because they are in the "inner circle" and not necessarily based on merit and potential.  If you are willing to stay for at least 10 years and align yourself to a Director or VP, then you have a shot.  It's about "WHO" you know, which is probably par for the course for a company of this size.

Benefits are below standard at best.

review_title: Great projects in strong manufacturing environment
pros: Interns were treated with respect and given meaningful projects to work on. I enjoyed working there for the summer, and the salary/housing stipend was very competitive.
cons: There were some problems between the manufacturing operators and the engineers that sometimes made certain processes and tasks slower and more complicated than they needed to be. This is probably the case at many places though.

pros: 100% flex time. You pick your schedule, and rarely have overtime (excluding 24/7 call, which rotates among team members). Great time off, some good perks (free online tech books, gym memberships) Relaxed work environment with technically adept people.
cons: The benefits (health) suck and look to get worse in the future. Management often rewards itself with cash bonuses and employees get a pizza party. Other than that, really not that bad.

review_title: Interesting work, great people, very bureaucratic
pros: Interesting and often challenging work. Decent compensation and benefits. Has offices everywhere so it is easy to move around. Good work/life balance (some places have 10/40 schedule).
cons: Very bureaucratic but I suppose that is to be expected at a mega defense contractor. Career advancement can be slow. Young energetic high-performing employees are not fairly rewarded for their contributions. Big raises and promotions seem to be more about years-of-service than performance/ability.

review_title: A Place where most people will help you to succeed
pros: High Ethical standards and a desire to "do the right thing". Compensation is good and benefits are excellent compared to most other employers. Brilliant people to work with. Those at the very top of the company are impressive, smart and capable of guiding this company thru difficult economical times.
cons: workforce reductions have meant more work for fewer people. Depending on your role, the workload and demand on your schedule can be burdensome.

review_title: One of the worst experience of my 20+ year defense career!
pros: Pay is average-good (not great) for similar jobs!
cons:
Lockheed is very top heavy, and too many layers of incompetent & redundant management. HR is basically an arm of the management and does not really care if the employee is being done harm. HR does not represent the employees, only the management. Can not get an honest and straight forward answer or support from management on most "real"issues. Layoffs are common and there is a general fear among most employees (unless you are a part of the selected
inner-click) about lack of job security. The annual performance appraisals are very subjective with the employees having very little meaningful recourse to challenge an unfair assessment. Performance Analysis have company and management agenda as a driver that always trumps a fair and objective employee assesment; same goes with tiny annual salary increases, if you are lucky to get one in the first place. Most of the jobs require high security clearance, but trying to get specific answers from the company  security office is a very frustrating & the norm is the individual never gets a clear answer about their security investigation.

Lockheed like many other similar size companies like to hire from pet schools (with a small number from non-pet schools which is really a smoke screen to hide the  biasness in their company wide hiring process), and generally those few from pet schools are given opportunity for the management path & entry into ELDP programs.  A lot of Electrical, Civil and Mechaical/Aerospace engineers are hired but then many are pushed to do stuff completely unrelated with their educational background for prolonged periods of time, causing them to loose critical technical skills learnt in college; 

A huge company but many layers of highly paid but redundant management can be cut to make it more streamline and agile; unfortunately the non-management employees are cut first. Finally, the "broadly understood meaning and concept of Diversity" is completely altered in this company to maintain the status-quo; Lockheed brags about Diversity in its advertisements but the truth is most (~ 90%) of the middle and upper management & leadership is either white men and white women; but very little percentage of African Americans, Asians and Hispanics are represented in the middle and top leadership of the company. There is a systemic effort to continue with the status-quo behind the drum beating of diversity. Sadly, these problems are alive in most business areas of Lockheed Martin and not just in the IS&GS business area that I work in.

review_title: OK place to start a career with reasonable career growth opportunities
job_title: Systems/Software Engineer In Space Systems in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
- Great benefits (3 wks vacation/yr that are cumulative up to 10 wks, 401k, health coverage, employee discounts, free local transit, etc.)
- Good amount of travel opportunities (got to rack up those FF points in my first few years)
- Tuition reimbursement (10.5k/yr for graduate engineering degree)
- Good rotational programs available for leadership development
- Overtime/comp time available for excess hours you work
- For most positions, decent work/life balance with fairly flexible hours and opportunity for personal time off
- Overall, strong aerospace company to work for with a lot of interesting projects if aerospace is your career goal; motivated and charismatic employees shouldn't have much issue working their way up or finding challenging projects to work on
cons:
- Enormous company with many, many, many layers of middle management, most of whom have too little power to influence positive change and too little technical skills to understand what's actually going on in the trenches
- Preponderance of government contract work means you will have paperwork and red tape in your day-to-day, and loads of it
- Compensation/promotions disproportionately reliant on people skills rather than technical performance; career growth dependent on penetrating and socializing with maximal layers of management
- Risk averse on most projects, with strong tendency to stick with what works and not what's best
- Tools made available to employees is usually unsatisfactory; difficult to get extra monitors/computing accessories, computing resources are sub-par with tons of extraneous bloat for security software, don't even ask about open-source/freeware tools, most employees still use IE7 and most company tools only work with IE, etc.
- Restricted access to outside world (e.g. no GMail, many sites blocked/restricted which makes searching for online answers difficult at times, no music streaming, etc.); if you work in a classified area, you do not have access to your cell phone or the external web
- Skills you develop are generally applicable to only the aerospace industry; processes are quite rigid and tools that you use are likely out of date, even if you are indeed working on cutting edge products
- Overall, constipated work environment tends to stifle innovation and creativity, and tends to soften young engineers in an era that is all about the technological bleeding edge

pros:
Get to work on some of the most amazing assemblies, including satellites and fighter jets.
Good work-life balance (depending on your work group).  Flex-time.
Great leadership development programs (including generous tuition reimbursement) for early career employees.
cons:
Too much bureaucracy throughout company and industry.
Downturn in defense industry, with concerns of sequestration.

review_title: Continue the job search after you technically hav a job already
pros: If you have the patience to wait for procurements and such, you have access to some of the best in technology development and substantial resources.
cons: In California, because the cost of real estate and employee salaries tends to be the highest in the country, we are often the last to receive contracts and also the first to be cut.

job_title: Staff Systems Engineer in Owego, NY
pros: LM provides opportunities to work on large-scale complex projects of national importance. Employees are encouraged to take advantage of training opportunities. Most employees are highly qualified. This organization offers different career advancement paths depending on interests/qualifications (e.g. scientists, engineers, MBAs).
cons: Annual reviews require managers to identify a specific percentage of employees as poor performers (even if they estimate that some individuals do not deserve to be categorized as such...)

job_title: Proposal Analyst Senior in Herndon, VA
pros: There's always something to do from proposal pricing, analysis, communicating internally with your counterparts and customers from all over the nation. I formed some really good relationships with employees from this company.
cons: Long hours, lack of work/life balance, pricing system can go down while you're working late into the night and then the customer could potentially change requirements on you at the last minute when you're almost done (that's kind of normal).

review_title: Great place to work, if you perform and work for the right organization/leader/boss.  Salary is fairly competitive.
pros: Flexible work schedule, interesting challenges, great people.  Decent benefits and 401k plan; promotes from within fairly regularly.
cons: Same shortfalls you'd see in Corporate America; still a lot of dead weight around that you can't just get rid of. 20 percent of the workforce still does 80 percent of the work.

pros:
Entry level opportunities
Health care
9/80 schedule
Vacation time
cons:
High stress job
After 2 years of work, hard to move up
Performance rating system
Company systems
poor communication
management conflicts and styles
unwilling to change culture
